revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1861 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National Association of Base Ball Players]] champion – [[Brooklyn Atlantics]] '''Events''' * The [[NABBP|National Association]] establishes the December annual meeting, a change from March, meeting twice during calendar 1860. Membership slips from 59 to 55 clubs and then the outbreak of the [[American Civil War]] in the spring sharply cuts both inter-city travel and the number of matches played in greater New York City. Some clubs practically disband.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 18 June — [[Jem Mace]] defeats [[Sam Hurst]] in eight rounds at Medway Island to win the Heavyweight Championship of England. Hurst retires from boxing.<ref name="JM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/mace-j.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Jem Mace]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * [[John C. Heenan]] retains the Championship of America but there is no record of any fights involving him in 1861.<ref name="JH">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/heenan.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – John C. Heenan]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * 20 October — [[English cricket team in Australia in 1861–62|the first English team to tour Australia]] sets sail from Liverpool. The team is captained by [[H. H. Stephenson]]. No first-class matches are played. '''England''' * Most runs – [[Robert Carpenter (cricketer)|Robert Carpenter]] 883 @ 30.44 (HS 106) * Most wickets – [[Edgar Willsher]] 87 @ 11.65 (BB 8–27)
==[[Football]]== '''Events''' * Foundation of [[Richmond F.C.|Richmond FC]] and [[Sale Sharks]] which are two of the oldest senior [[rugby union]] clubs
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1861 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Tom Morris, Sr.|Tom Morris senior]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Events''' * The inaugural running of the [[Melbourne Cup]] in Australia is won by [[Archer (horse)|Archer]]. The Melbourne Cup is a race for three-year-olds and above, over a distance of 3,200 metres (approximately two miles). '''England''' * [[1861 Grand National|Grand National]] – Jealousy * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Nemesis * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Diophantus * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Kettledrum (horse)|Kettledrum]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Brown Duchess * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Caller Ou '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – [[Archer (horse)|Archer]] '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Wild Irishman
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 23 March — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 18th [[The Boat Race 1861|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] '''Other events''' * [[Harvard–Yale Regatta]] – ''not contested 1861 to 1863''
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
[[Image:50s Topps Logo.jpg|thumb|right|Brand name printed on the merchandise in the 1950s]] [[Topps]] joined the sports cards market in the 1950s becoming a rival to [[Bowman Gum|Bowman]]. After competing with each other for five years Topps bought out Bowman in 1956. Competition still remained however, in the form of [[Parkhurst Products|Parkhurst]] [[hockey cards]]. Topps produced cards of the United States-based [[National Hockey League]] teams while Parkhurst covered the Canadian teams. Topps had produced multi-sport photo cards prior to 1950, namely the 1948 Topps Magic Photos but each set was very small and not considered a major set.{{cite web|url=http://www.psacard.com/articles/article_view.chtml?artid=5071&universeid=314&type=1 |title=The Battle for Football Card Supremacy Begins: A Look at the 1950 Bowman Football Set – PSA Library |publisher=Psacard.com |date= |accessdate=2008-09-06}} This trend was consistent with their first baseball and college football issues: the 1950 Feltbacks resembled college pennants; 1951 Magic football included a scratch-off game on the reverse; Red/Blue Backs intended to be a card game; Connie Mack/Current All-Stars are foldable stand-ups. It was in 1952 that Topps released their first truly major card set. In the autumn of 1951, [[Woody Gelman]] and [[Sy Berger]], then a 28-year-old veteran of World War II, designed the 1952 [[Topps]] [[baseball card]] set on the kitchen table of Berger's apartment on Alabama Avenue in [[Brooklyn, New York|Brooklyn]].Mint Condition: How Baseball Cards Became an American Obsession, p. 90, Dave Jamieson, 2010, Atlantic Monthly Press, imprint of Grove/Atlantic Inc., New York, {{ISBN|978-0-8021-1939-1}} The 1957 Topps set featured dimensions of 2½ by 3½ inches which has become known as the standard card size. Below is a list with brief descriptions of Topps [[trading card]] products for the 1950s. ==Baseball== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !Year !Set !Quantity !Size(in.) !Distribution1 |- |rowspan=5|1951 |Blue Backs |52 |2 × {{frac|2|5|8}} in (5.1 × 6.7 cm) |Wax (2), Rack (all) |- |Red Backs |52 |2 × {{frac|2|5|8}} in (5.1 × 6.7 cm) |Wax (2), Rack (all) |- |[[Connie Mack]] [[All-Stars]] |11 |{{frac|2|1|16}} × {{frac|5|1|4}} in (5.2 × 13.3 cm) |Wax (1), Rack (#) |- |Current All-Stars |8 |{{frac|2|1|16}} × {{frac|5|1|4}} in (5.2 × 13.3 cm) |Wax (2), Rack (#) |- |Team Cards |9 |{{frac|2|1|16}} × {{frac|5|1|4}} in (5.2 × 13.3 cm) |Wax (2), Rack (#) |- |rowspan=2|1952 |Topps |407 |{{frac|2|5|8}} × {{frac|3|3|4}} in (6.7 × 9.5 cm) |Wax (1,6), Cello (#) |- |Master set |487 |{{frac|2|5|8}} × {{frac|3|3|4}} in (6.7 × 9.5 cm) |Wax (1,6), Cello (#) |- |1953 |Topps |274 |{{frac|2|5|8}} × {{frac|3|3|4}} in (6.7 × 9.5 cm) |Wax (1,6), Cello (#) |- |rowspan=2|1954 |Topps |250 |{{frac|2|5|8}} × {{frac|3|3|4}} in (6.7 × 9.5 cm) |Wax (1,6), Cello (15) |- |Canadian |50 |{{frac|2|5|8}} × {{frac|3|3|4}} in (6.7 × 9.5 cm) |- |rowspan=2|1955 |Topps |206 |{{frac|2|5|8}} × {{frac|3|3|4}} in (6.7 × 9.5 cm) |Wax (1,6), Cello (15) |- |Double Header |66 |{{frac|2|1|16}} × {{frac|4|7|8}} in (5.2 × 12.4 cm) |Wax (1) |- |rowspan=2|1956 |Topps |340 |{{frac|2|5|8}} × {{frac|3|3|4}} in (6.7 × 9.5 cm) |Wax (1,6), Cello (15) |- |Pins |60 |{{frac|1|3|16}} in (3 cm) diameter |Box (1) |- |1957 |Topps |407 |2.5 × 3.5 in (6.4 × 8.9 cm) |Wax (1,6), Cello (12) |- |rowspan=2|1958 |Topps |494 |2.5 × 3.5 in (6.4 × 8.9 cm) |Wax (1,6), Cello (12) |- |Master set |534 |2.5 × 3.5 in (6.4 × 8.9 cm) |Wax (1,6), Cello (12) |- |rowspan=2|1959 |Topps |572 |2.5 × 3.5 in (6.4 × 8.9 cm) |Wax (1,6), Cello (12) |- |Bazooka |23 |{{frac|2|13|16}} × {{frac|4|15|16}} in (7.1 × 12.5 cm) |Box Panel (1) |- |} 1 Pack type(card quantity)
# indicates varying quantity ===Licensed sets=== Beginning in 1959, Topps began permitting the printing of cards by a printer (Benco) in Venezuela on account of it being a viable baseball market. The most significant difference from the U.S. issue was the card stock quality used for the Venezuelan cards. Two distinctly different card stocks were used (one with gray backs, the other with cream backs), and both were of much lower grade. Cards from this set have a duller finish on the front due to no gloss being applied. Approximately half of the set has a copyright designation which states the card was printed in the US, while the other half state 'Impreso en Venezuela por Benco CA'. The 1959 Venezuelan set features cards 1-198 [http://i274.photobucket.com/albums/jj262/josh48067/198C-Davenport-4.jpg 1959 Venezuela Topps Jim Davenport #198 image] from their U.S. counterpart. (It has been long believed that the set consisted of only 196 cards, however, it has been found to have been incorrectly documented for years with card #198 having been validated by independent third-party agency PSA as being from the set). Size: 2.5 × 3.5 inches. ==Football== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !Year !Set !Quantity !Size (in.) !Notes |- |1950 |Felt Backs |100 |{{frac|7|8}} × {{frac|1|7|16}} in (2.2 × 3.7 cm) |[[College football]] |- |1951 |Magic |75 |{{frac|2|1|16}} × {{frac|2|15|16}} in (5.2 × 7.5 cm) |College football |- |1955 |All-American |100 |{{frac|2|5|8}} × {{frac|3|5|8}} in (6.7 × 9.2 cm) |College football |- |1956 |Topps |120 |{{frac|2|5|8}} × {{frac|3|3|4}} in (6.7 × 9.5 cm) |[[National Football League|NFL]] |- |1957 |Topps |154 |2.5 × 3.5 in (6.4 × 8.9 cm) |NFL |- |rowspan=2|1958 |Topps |132 |2.5 × 3.5 in (6.4 × 8.9 cm) |NFL |- |Topps CFL |88 |2.5 × 3.5 in (6.4 × 8.9 cm) |[[Canadian Football League|CFL]] |- |rowspan=3|1959 |Topps |176 |2.5 × 3.5 in (6.4 × 8.9 cm) |NFL |- |Topps CFL |88 |2.5 × 3.5 in (6.4 × 8.9 cm) |CFL |- |Bazooka |18 |{{frac|2|13|16}} × {{frac|4|15|16}} in (7.1 × 12.5 cm) |NFL |- |} ==Basketball== Topps' first basketball issue was released for 1957-58. The set has 80 cards of [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] players and was issued in 5-cent packs. Over half the set is rookies with 47. There were also 22 cards in the set that were double printed. The player's name and team appear in the lower portion of the photo in adjacent long and short trapezoid shaped bars respectively. The backs offer biographical player data with year and career statistics. Also on the backs, the card number appears on a backboard style design and a drawing of a player standing in front of a ruler indicates the player's height. After this issue, Topps did not release another basketball set until 1969. Size: 2.5 × 3.5 in. ==Ice hockey== ===1954–55=== {{Details|1954-55 Topps Hockey}} *The 1954–55 Topps hockey set was Topps' first attempt at producing trading cards for the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL). At the time, the league consisted of six teams known as the [[Original Six]]. Topps included all four American teams in this popular 60-card set – [[Boston Bruins]], [[Chicago Blackhawks|Chicago Black Hawks]], [[Detroit Red Wings]], and [[New York Rangers]]. ===1957–1959=== The players in these sets are from the four U.S. based teams of the NHL. Bilingual backs(English/French) feature previous season statistics, a short player biography and a cartoon question and answer section. ====1957–58==== * Base set 66 cards Size: 2.5 × 3.5 inches ====1958–59==== * Base set 66 cards Size: 2.5 × 3.5 inches ====1959–60==== * Base set 66 cards Size: 2.5 × 3.5 inches ==Boxing== '''1951 Topps Ringside''' Topps' only boxing issue came out in 1951 and was called 'Ringside'. The set featured current and former boxing stars as well as wrestlers. The set totals 96 color cards with biographical information on the back. Some of the cards depicted a championship belt above the athlete's name indicating their weight class and year(s) they held the title. ==Multi-sport== '''1955 Hocus Focus''' The second issue of Magic Photos came in 1955. This set included 23 baseball players and a number of other series covering several topical areas. Size: {{frac|7|8}} × {{frac|1|3|8}} inches '''1956 Hocus Focus''' This set was similar in that it was a series of subsets featuring various sports and non-sport subjects. Among them are aircraft, buildings, world leaders, actors, submarines, automobiles, and famous landmarks. Size: {{frac|7|8}} × {{frac|1|7|16}} in (2.2 × 3.7 cm) ==Non-sport== The sets listed below cover a variety of subject matter from Television and Movie personalities to Cars and Planes. Topps' offerings for non-sport sets were not limited to cards. A number of the issues were tattoos, stamps, coins and the well known [[Bazooka Joe]] and [[Archie comics|Archie Comics]]. Set information is listed here by Year, Set Name, Quantity of Cards(#), and the card's Dimensions in inches. ===1950=== *Bring 'Em Back Alive (100) 2{{fraction|1|16}} × 2⅝ * Hopalong Cassidy (238) 2{{fraction|1|16}} × 2⅝ * Hoppy Pops Puzzles 8¼ square * License Plates (75) 1¾ × 2⅞ * Rudolph Pops 8¼ square ===1950-51=== * Freedom's War (203) 2{{fraction|1|16}} × 2⅝ ===1951=== * Animals of the World (100) 2{{fraction|1|16}} × 2⅝ ===1952=== * Look 'N See (135) 2{{fraction|1|16}} × 2{{fraction|15|16}} * Wings (200) 2⅝ × 3¾ ===1953=== * Fighting Marines (96) 2{{fraction|1|16}} × 2{{fraction|15|16}} * License Plates (75) 1⅞ × 3¾ * Tarzan & The She Devil (60) 2⅝ × 3¾ * Tarzan's Savage Fury (60) 2⅝ × 3¾ * Who-Z-At Star (80) 2⅝ × 3¾ ===1954=== * Scoop (156) 2{{fraction|1|16}} × 2{{fraction|15|16}} ===1955=== * Funny Foldees (66) 1{{fraction|3|16}} × 1{{fraction|9|16}} * Rails and Sails (200) 2⅝ × 3¾ ===1956=== * Davy Crockett (160) 2⅝ × 3¾ * Davy Crockett {{sic|hide=y|Tatoos}} 1{{fraction|9|16}} × 3½ * Elvis Presley (66) 2.5 × 3.5 * Flags of the World (80) 2⅝ × 3¾ * [[1957 Topps Planes Cards|Jets]] (240) 2{{fraction|1|16}} × 2{{fraction|15|16}} * Round-Up (80) 2⅝ × 3¾ * U.S. Presidents (36) 2½ × 3¾ ===1957=== * Goofy Series Post Cards (60) 2.5 × 3.5 * Hit Stars (88) 2.5 × 3.5 * Isolation Booth (88) 2.5 × 3.5 * [[1957 Topps Planes Cards|Planes]] (120) 2.5 × 3.5 * Robin Hood (60) 2.5 × 3.5 * Space Cards/Target: Moon (88) 2.5 × 3.5 ===1958=== * T.V. Westerns (71) 2.5 × 3.5 * Zorro (88) 2.5 × 3.5 ===1959=== * The Fabulous Fabian (55) 2.5 × 3.5 * Funny Valentines (66) 2.5 × 3.5 * Wacky Plaks (88) 2½ × 4⅝ * Woody Woodpecker {{sic|hide=y|Tatoos}} 1{{fraction|9|16}} × 3½ * Funny Monsters (66) 2.5 × 3.5 ===Multi Year Issues=== * Freedom's War (203) 2{{fraction|1|16}} × 2⅝ (1950–1951) * World On Wheels (180) 2⅝ × 3¾ (1953–1955) * Archie Comics (~30) 2¾ × 3⅝ (1957–1958) * Popeye {{sic|hide=y|Tatoos}} 1{{fraction|9|16}} × 3½ (1958–1959) * Famous American Heroes (18) 7/8 × 1⅜ * Bazooka Joe ==Recommended Reading== *Slocum, Frank (1994). "Baseball cards of the fifties: the complete Topps cards, 1950–1959". Simon & Schuster-New York {{ISBN|0-671-89224-X}} *Bloom, John (1997). "A house of cards: baseball card collecting and popular culture". University of Minnesota Press-Minneapolis, Minnesota {{ISBN|0-8166-2870-X}} ==References== ==Sources== * Beckett, Dr. James et al. revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox rugby league biography |name = Albert Baskerville |fullname = Albert Henry Baskiville |nickname = |image = Albert baskerville.jpg |caption = |birth_date = 15 January 1883 to Henry William Baskiville & Maria Mace, at |birth_place = Waiorongomai, Te Aroha, New Zealand |death_date = 20 May 1908 (aged 25) |death_place = [[Brisbane, Queensland]], Australia |height = |weight = |position = {{rlp|WG}} |teamA = [[New Zealand national rugby league team|New Zealand]] |yearAstart = 1907 |yearAend = 08 |appearancesA = 1 |triesA = 1 |goalsA = 0 |fieldgoalsA = 0 |pointsA = 3 |updated = |source = <ref name="Statistics at rugbyleagueproject.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/players/Albert_Baskerville/summary.html|title=Statistics at rugbyleagueproject.org|publisher=rugbyleagueproject.org|date=31 December 2017|accessdate=1 January 2018}}</ref> }} '''Albert (Bert) Henry Baskerville''' (born as '''"Baskiville"'''<ref name=SeanFaganBaskerville>{{cite web|author=[[Sean Fagan]]|title=Albert Baskerville – Or Baskiville?|url=http://www.rl1908.com/articles/Baskerville.htm|accessdate=28 June 2008|work=rl1908.com/index.htm RL1908|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517144647/http://www.rl1908.com/articles/Baskerville.htm|archivedate=17 May 2008|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>) (15 January 1883 – 20 May 1908) was a [[Wellington]] postal clerk, a [[rugby union]] forward, author of the book "''Modern Rugby Football: New Zealand Methods; Points for the Beginner, the Player, the Spectator''" and a pioneer of [[rugby league]].
==Rugby football== Prior to becoming the administrator of the 1908 tour Baskerville played rugby for the Oriental club in Wellington and was said to be on the verge of [[Wellington Rugby Union|provincial selection]].<ref name=book>John Haynes ''From All Blacks to All Golds: Rugby League's Pioneers'', Christchurch, Ryan and Haynes, 1996. {{ISBN|0-473-03864-1}}</ref> His father had been killed in 1903 and Bert had been the main [[income earner]] for the family since then.<ref name=book /> His book, ''Modern Rugby Football: New Zealand Methods; Points for the Beginner, the Player, the Spectator'', was published in 1907 and gave him somewhat of a national profile. After the success of this project he moved on to his next ambitious idea, a professional rugby tour of Great Britain.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://allgolds.net/ |title=The All Golds |access-date=4 September 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171010124413/http://www.allgolds.net/ |archive-date=10 October 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==The Tour== {{Main|1907–1908 New Zealand rugby tour of Great Britain}} Baskerville wrote to the [[Rugby Football League|Northern Union]] and asked if they would host a touring party of New Zealand rugby players. The Northern Union were excited by this proposal and quickly agreed. After this Baskerville began to work on organising the tour full-time, leaving his job at the Postal Department and severing his connection with the Oriental Football Club. The [[Wellington Rugby Union]] moved quickly to attempt to stop him from attending their grounds and he received a life ban from the [[New Zealand Rugby Union]]. Despite this he managed to put together an impressive touring party that included eight [[All Blacks]], including four from the 1905 [[The Original All Blacks|tour of Great Britain]]. The team was dubbed the [[1907-1908 New Zealand rugby tour of Great Britain|All Golds]] by the Sydney press, a derogatory play on the New Zealand rugby union team's nickname the [[All Blacks]].
The tour was a great success both financially, each player earned roughly £300, and on the field, where the touring side won consecutive Test series against Great Britain and Australia. For most of the tour Baskerville was busy with the administration work and it was not until the final game of the British leg, against [[St Helens R.F.C.]], that Baskerville played, scoring a try. On arriving in Australia he then played in the [[1907–08 New Zealand rugby tour of Australia and Great Britain#1908 in Australia|first ever trans-Tasman test]] which was the debut match of the [[Australia national rugby league team]], again scoring a try. Tragically that was to be the only time that Baskerville would represent [[New Zealand Kiwis|New Zealand]] in a Test match. Baskerville contracted [[pneumonia]] on the ship taking the touring party from Sydney to Brisbane and, after several days in hospital, died aged 25 in [[Brisbane]], Australia on 20 May 1908.<ref name=SeanFaganCentenaryUpdates>{{cite web|author=[Sean Fagan Sean Fagan]|title=2008 RUGBY LEAGUE CENTENARY NEWS & UPDATES|url=http://www.rl1908.com/Centenary/nz-allgolds-august17th.htm|accessdate=28 June 2008|work=rl1908.com/index.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080506140540/http://www.rl1908.com/Centenary/nz-allgolds-august17th.htm|archive-date=6 May 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> His body was taken by manager Harry Palmer and a group of players from each province back to Wellington. The rest of the touring party stayed in Australia to complete their remaining fixtures. Like five other members of the touring party Baskerville is buried at Karori Cemetery.<ref>[http://www.rleague.com/db/article.php?id=29312 Relatives and Teams to remember Original All Golds] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012183957/http://rleague.com/db/article.php?id=29312 |date=12 October 2007}} ''NZRL Press Release'', 10 October 2007</ref>
==Legacy==
{{Quotation|It was he who practically originated the professional Rugby movement in Australasia|''[[The Sydney Mail]]'', 27 May 1908<ref>{{cite news | title = A. H. Baskerville | work=[[The Sydney Mail]] | place = Australia | pages = 1414 | date = 27 May 1908 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZIAQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=s5UDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5115,3143048 | archive-url = https://archive.is/20130124153347/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZIAQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=s5UDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5115,3143048 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 24 January 2013 | accessdate =20 November 2009}}</ref>}}On their return from Australia the remaining members of the tour party held a memorial game, the first game of rugby league in New Zealand, and raised £300 for his widowed mother.<ref name=book />
The [[Courtney Goodwill Trophy]], international rugby league′s first, was presented for the first time in 1936 and depicted Baskiville, along with other pioneering greats of the code, [[Jean Galia]] (France), [[James Lomas (rugby league)|James Lomas]] (England) and [[Dally Messenger]] (Australia).<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090914123213/http://www.nsm.org.au/Whats%20On/Latest%20News/2009/April/~/media/Files/Rugby_League_Fast_Facts.ashx “League Legends: fast facts about rugby league”] at ''nsm.org.au''</ref>
He is commemorated by the naming of the [[Baskerville Shield]], the trophy awarded when [[Great Britain national rugby league team|Great Britain]] and [[New Zealand national rugby league team|New Zealand]] meet in test series. In 2001 Baskerville was inducted as one of the [[NZRL]] Legends of League.<ref>{{cite web | vauthors = | title = New Zealand Rugby League Annual Report 2008 | publisher=NZRL | year = 2008 | url = http://www.nzrl.co.nz/files/financials/nzrl_2008annualreport_part1.pdf | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090912205939/http://www.nzrl.co.nz/files/financials/nzrl_2008annualreport_part1.pdf | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 12 September 2009 | format = pdf | accessdate =21 July 2009}}</ref>
==See also== *[[2007 All Golds Tour|2007 "All Golds" Tour]] – celebrating the centenary of Baskerville's 1907 Tour. *[[History of Rugby League]]
==References== {{reflist|40em}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090106192527/http://www.rlhalloffame.org.uk/baskiville.htm Rugby League Hall of Fame Baskiville page] *[http://www.nzhalloffame.co.nz/custom_extras/nzhalloffame/inductee.asp?inducteeid=12 Albert Baskerville at nzhalloffame.co.nz]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Denman Arena | nickname = | image = Denman arena 1913.jpg | caption = Photograph of Denman Arena in 1913 | fullname = | location = Georgia Street at Denman Street, [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = December 26, 1911 | closed = | demolished = 1936 | owner = Vancouver Arena Company Limited | operator = | surface = mechanically frozen ice | construction_cost = $226,382{{sfn|Wong|2009|p=236}} | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Vancouver Millionaires]] ([[Pacific Coast Hockey Association|PCHA]]) (1911–1926)
[[New Westminster Royals]] (PCHA) (1911–1914)
[[Vancouver Lions]] ([[Pacific Coast Hockey League|PCHL]], [[North West Hockey League|NWHL]]) (1928–1936) | seating_capacity = 10,500 | dimensions = 210 ft x 85 ft (surface) }} [[File:DenmanArena Vancouver.jpg|thumb|Denman Arena from the southwest]] '''Denman Arena''' was an indoor [[arena]] located in downtown [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]. The arena was located at 1805 [[Georgia Street|West Georgia Street]] at the northwest corner with Denman Street. It opened in December 1911 and was destroyed by fire in 1936. Its primary use was for ice sports such as [[ice hockey]]. It was the home [[ice rink]] of the [[Vancouver Millionaires]] professional ice hockey team, and was the location of 1915 [[Stanley Cup Finals|Stanley Cup championships]]. The arena was also used for other sports, musical performances and public assemblies. It was an assembly point for Canadian servicemen during [[World War I]]. The 10,500 seat arena was the largest in Canada at the time, and introduced mechanically frozen or "artificial" ice to Canada.{{sfn|Wong|2009|p=234}} ==Construction== In January 1911, Joe Patrick sold his [[Nelson, British Columbia]] lumber business for $440,000.{{sfn|Wong|2009|p=233}} The Patrick family moved to [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]] and the decision was made to use the proceeds of the company sale to go into the business of professional ice hockey. The family built the Denman Arena to support the new [[Pacific Coast Hockey Association]] professional ice hockey league, to be run by Joe's sons [[Frank Patrick (hockey)|Frank]] and [[Lester Patrick]]. Both Frank and Lester were professional ice hockey players and had played in the [[National Hockey Association]] and other early professional leagues in Eastern Canada. Simultaneously, the Patricks also built the 4000-seat [[Patrick Arena]] in Victoria. To build the Vancouver arena, the Patricks bought a parcel of land consisting of thirteen lots from the water's edge of Coal Harbour to Georgia Street, bounded by Denman and Chilco Streets. The location was near [[Stanley Park]] to the west, and was connected to the downtown business district by a streetcar line along Georgia Street.{{sfn|Wong|2009|pp=234–235}} The site was previously the location of the Kanaka Ranch, which was settled in the 1860s by Hawaiian families, who grew fruit and vegetables, and produced charcoal, on the site.{{cite web |publisher=Vancouver Historical Society |title=Historical Markers in Vancouver Parks |url=http://www.vancouver-historical-society.ca/historical_markers.htm |accessdate=November 28, 2013}} To finance the construction of the Arena, the Patricks formed the Vancouver Arena Company Limited, capitalized at $200,000. The company was divided into 1000 preferred shares and 1000 common shares, with a 10% annual dividend. The company issued an initial share offering, but by September 1911, the offering had only raised $1400. Two more investors signed on, but it was up to the Paticks to take the rest.{{sfn|Wong|2009|pp=235–236}} To facilitate the playing of ice hockey in Vancouver's moderate climate, the Patricks imported mechanical ice freezing equipment that Frank and Lester Patrick had seen in operation at New York's [[St. Nicholas Arena]]. The Denman Arena opened on December 20, 1911, attracting 1500 people for a session of public [[ice skating]].{{sfn|Wong|2009|p=236}} Denman Arena held 10,500 people, making it at the time, the largest indoor arena in Canada, one of the world's largest indoor arenas, and the second largest indoor arena in [[North America]], after the second [[Madison Square Garden (1890)|Madison Square Garden]] in [[New York City]].{{sfn|Wong|2009|p=236}} The Arena was built at a cost of $226,382.{{sfn|Wong|2009|p=236}} In 1927, the Patricks built the 2,500 seat Denman Auditorium next to the Arena. The Auditorium, which was multi-purpose, survived the fire of 1936 and was renovated in 1952. It re-opened on September 10, 1952 as the Georgia Auditorium concert hall.{{cite news |newspaper=Vancouver Sun |date=September 11, 1952 |title=Auditorium Changes Achieve Purpose |page=31}} It only lasted seven years before it was demolished in 1959, after the construction of the [[Queen Elizabeth Theatre]]. ==Usage== The Arena was the permanent home of the professional [[Vancouver Millionaires]] of the [[Pacific Coast Hockey Association]]. The Arena was also the home of the [[New Westminster Royals]] from 1911 until 1914. The Patricks had hoped to set up teams in [[Calgary]] and [[Edmonton]] in the PCHA for the opening season, but the plans fell through. To avoid having a two-team league, the Patricks formed the Royals, to represent the neighbouring town of [[New Westminster]] and encourage fans to come to the Arena. Although the Royals were an unexpected necessity, the Royals were the winners of the first PCHA championship. The Royals were disbanded in 1914, when the PCHA formed a team in [[Portland, Oregon]]. The Millionaires were later renamed the Maroons and were disbanded in 1926 when the [[Western Canada Hockey League]] discontinued operations. The Arena hosted the [[Stanley Cup]] "World Series" championship series four times. The [[1915 Stanley Cup Finals|1915 series]] pitted the Millionaires versus the [[National Hockey Association]]'s [[Ottawa Senators (original)|Ottawa Senators]], the first Stanley Cup series held west of [[Winnipeg]]. The series was won by the Millionaires, and remains the only Stanley Cup won by a Vancouver team. The Arena also hosted Stanley Cup series in [[1921 Stanley Cup Final|1921]], won by Ottawa, the [[1923 Stanley Cup Final|1923]] series won by Ottawa and game two of the [[1925 Stanley Cup Final|1925 series]], won by the [[Victoria Cougars]]. During construction, the Patricks organized a four-team amateur ice hockey league, the Vancouver Amateur Hockey League, composed of the Vancouver Athletic Club, the Bankers, the Columbians and the Vancouver Rowing Club.{{sfn|Wong|2009|p=239}} In 1921, the Arena hosted the first international women's championship of ice hockey, organized by the PCHA.{{sfn|Norton|2009|p=115}} After the collapse of the Western Canada league, a new [[Pacific Coast Hockey League]] was organized, with the [[Vancouver Lions]] playing out of the Arena.{{sfn|Whitehead|p=178}} The PCHL lasted three years. In 1933, the Lions were revived in the [[North West Hockey League]]. The Lions continued after the destruction of the Arena, and a reconstituted PCHL began operations with the Lions as a member. Two other ice sports clubs had their start at the Denman Arena. The Arena also had four [[curling]] rinks in the basement and the [[Vancouver Curling Club]] was established in December 1911.{{sfn|Wong|2009|p=240}} Curling was discontinued during World War I to make way for the armed forces. The Club re-organized in 1931 at the [[Pacific National Exhibition]]'s Forum. The Club built its own facility in 1949.{{cite web |publisher=Vancouver Curling Club |title=History |url=http://www.vancouvercurlingclub.com/history |accessdate=December 2, 2013}} The Connaught Skating Club also was established in December 1911,{{sfn|Wong|2009|p=240}} and celebrated its 100th anniversary in 2011.{{cite news |newspaper=Richmond Review |title= Skaters celebrate 100 years|url=http://www.richmondreview.com/sports/119356754.html |first=Don |last=Fennell |accessdate=December 1, 2013 |date=April 7, 2011}} During the 1920s, the Club held competitions and an annual "Carnival" show at the Arena. After the Arena burned down, Connaught moved to the Forum as well, and in 1965 moved to [[Richmond, British Columbia]] to Richmond's Minoru Arena. The Arena and Auditorium were also used for boxing and wrestling matches. The North Shore Indians of the Inter-City League played [[box lacrosse]] in the Arena in the 1930s.{{cite news |newspaper=Vancouver Sun |title=A loving look at lacrosse |first=Archie |last=McDonald |date=August 14, 1982 |page=2}} In 1914, the Arena was used to house over 1,000 soldiers who were assembling to form the 23rd Infantry Brigade. The soldiers left Vancouver in August 1914 to be deployed as the first Canadian troops in [[World War I]].{{cite book |title=Greetings from British Columbia: A Journey in Vintage Postcards |page=162 |first1=Fred |last1=Thirkell |first2=Bob |last2=Scullion |year=2009 |publisher=Heritage House Publishing Co}} On October 21, 1924, the Arena was the site of a political radio broadcast by Canadian Prime Minister [[William Lyon Mackenzie King]], who spoke at Denman Arena during a tour of the west. It may have been the first political broadcast in Canada. Later that year, the telephone line installed was used for the first radio broadcast of an ice hockey game in British Columbia.{{cite book |title=Sound Heritage Series, Issues 35-38 |pages=15, 53 |author=Provincial Archives of British Columbia, Sound and Moving Image Division}} On April 28, 1935, over 16,000 assembled at the Arena for a political rally by the [[Co-operative Commonwealth Federation|CCF]], the largest indoor gathering in Vancouver up until that time.{{cite book |title=Vancouver Past: Essays in Social History |editor-first=Robert A. J. |editor-last=McDonald |page=265 |publisher=UBC Press}} The Denman Auditorium was taken over during World War II by the Canadian navy, then used as storage by Boeing Aircraft. It was bought in 1945 by H. M. Singer, who converted it back to a venue.{{cite news |newspaper=Regina Leader-Post |title=Georgia auditorium shuts down |page=4 |date=June 22, 1959}} Two notable [[rock and roll]] concerts took place in 1957, by a touring group of musicians known as "The Biggest Show of Stars." The lineup included [[Paul Anka]], [[Chuck Berry]], [[Eddie Cochran]], [[Fats Domino]], [[The Drifters]], [[The Everly Brothers]], [[Buddy Holly]], [[Buddy Knox]] and others.{{cite web |url=http://tomhawthorn.blogspot.ca/2009_02_01_archive.html |title=A Vancouver legend's brush with Buddy Holly |first=Tom |last=Hawthorne |accessdate=December 2, 2013}} The [[Vancouver Symphony Orchestra]] regularly played at the venue during the 1950s. The final event at the Georgia Auditorium took place on June 19, 1959. It was a free show by the CBC Talent Caravan. Other musical performances at the Arena and Auditorium included performances by [[Maurice Ravel]], [[Dizzy Gillespie]], [[Glenn Gould]], [[Charlie Parker]], [[Oscar Peterson]], [[Ella Fitzgerald]], [[Jeanette MacDonald]], [[Margaret Truman]] and others. ==Destruction by fire== The Arena was built of wood in 1911. Not long before 1936, the Arena was clad in brick to reduce its risk of burning due to fire. On the night of August 19, 1936, 4,000 fans had attended a boxing match by [[Max Baer (boxer)|Max Baer]]. By 1:30 AM that night, a fire had broken out in the adjacent Coal Harbour area. Despite the recently added brick veneer, the fire spread to inside the Arena. The interior exploded into flame and the Arena could not be saved by Vancouver firemen. Stan Patrick, the youngest brother of Frank and Lester Patrick, and manager of the auditorium,{{sfn|Whitehead|1980|p=213}} attended the fire and was quoted as saying "You think this is a good fire? You should have seen the one in Victoria. That was a pip!" A lack of wind prevented the huge fire from spreading into downtown Vancouver. The overall damage of the fire was estimated at $500,000. Two persons were killed and three firemen injured. The Arena was destroyed, along with seven industrial buildings, two homes and fifty-eight small boats.{{sfn|Whitehead|1980|p=213}} The concrete floor of the Arena was not destroyed, and it was adapted into an outdoor dance floor named the Starlight. In 1945, the site of the arena was sold by Lester Patrick to Vancouver theatre owner H. M. Singer for $80,000. Singer planned to build a $1 million sports arena on the site, but the arena was never built.{{cite news |work=Edmonton Journal |title=Vancouver Plans New Sports Arena |date=November 5, 1945 |page=6}} Singer managed the Auditorium as a concert venue until 1959. ==Site today== The site today is now part of Devonian Harbour Park. A historical marker has been placed at the foot of Denman Street, with information about the Arena, the Georgia Auditorium and Coal Harbour. ==References== ;Bibliography *{{cite book |first=Craig |last=Bowlsby |title=Empire of Ice: The Rise and Fall of the Pacific Coast Hockey Association, 1911-1926.}} * {{cite book |title=Women on Ice: The Early Years of Women's Hockey in Western Canada |first=Wayne |last=Norton |publisher=Ronsdale Press |year=2009 |isbn=978-1-55380-073-6 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |title=Cyclone Taylor: A Hockey Legend |first=Eric |last=Whitehead |year=1977 |publisher=Doubleday Canada |isbn=0385130635 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |title=The Patricks, hockey's royal family |first=Eric |last=Whitehead |year=1980 |publisher=Doubleday Canada |isbn=0385156626 |ref=harv}} *{{citation |last=Wong |first=John Chi-Kit|chapter=Boomtown Hockey |title=Coast to Coast: Hockey in Canada to the Second World War |year=2009 |editor-last=Wong |editor-first=John Chi-Kit|publisher=University of Toronto Press |isbn=978-0-8020-9532-9|ref=harv}} ;Notes {{reflist|refs= {{cite news |url=http://www.theprovince.com/sports/Empire+flames+1936+destruction+Denman+Arena/8802822/story.html |title=Empire of flames: The 1936 destruction of the Denman Arena |work=The Province |date=August 17, 2013 |first=Craig |last=Bowlsby}} }} {{coord|49|17|35|N|123|8|0|W|region:CA|display=title}} [[Category:Defunct indoor ice hockey venues in Canada]] [[Category:Sports venues in Vancouver]] [[Category:Defunct indoor arenas in Canada]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1911]] [[Category:Burned buildings and structures in Canada]] [[Category:1911 establishments in British Columbia]] [[Category:1936 disestablishments in Canada]]

{{Refimprove|date=July 2017}} {{Use South African English|date=July 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox venue | name = Ellis Park Arena | nickname = | image = | image_caption = | address = Bertrams Road
[[Doornfontein]], [[Johannesburg]], [[Gauteng]]
2094 [[South Africa]] | location = | coordinates = {{Coord|-26.1960512|28.0649668|type:landmark|display=title, inline}} | type = | genre = | built = | opened = {{Start date|1990}} | renovated = 2010 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Ellis Park World of Sport | construction_cost = | former_names = Standard Bank Arena (1990-2008) | seating_type = | seating_capacity = 6,300 | website = {{URL|http://www.lionsrugby.co.za/content/4492/4074/ellis-park-arena|Arena Information}} }} The '''Ellis Park Arena''' (formerly '''Standard Bank Arena''' and often acknowledged as '''Ellis Park Indoor Arena''') is an [[indoor arena|indoor sporting arena]] located in [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]]. The capacity of the arena is 5,000 people. A large number of sports events and concerts have occurred in this arena. The Ellis Park Arena has 4,300 permanent seats which give all spectators an unobstructed view. In addition there are retractable seats on the east and west sides on the floor for an additional 850 spectators. Chairs can also be placed on the floor up to a maximum of 1,200 making the capacity of the Arena approximately 6,300. There is a covered walkway around the Arena which includes a theatre style foyer, a fully licensed bar facility, as well as refreshment outlets and entertainment areas. Several suites in the Ellis Park Arena have a cocktail environment and can be used for private functions. While the Donald Ross Room accommodates 100 people, the VIP suite and Media Centre each cater for 200 people. The main foyer can accommodate up to 1,000 people. The arena hosted [[NBA Africa Game 2015]] on August 1, the first NBA-sanctioned game in Africa.http://www.nba.com/2015/news/07/16/nba-africa-game-2015-official-release/index.html?ls=iref:nbahpts It was contested between NBA players that were born in Africa or had parents born in the continent and players from the rest of the world.. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.ellispark.co.za/StandardBankArena.aspx Arena information] [[Category:Indoor arenas in South Africa]] [[Category:Sports venues in Johannesburg]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1990]] {{SouthAfrica-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox Radio Show | show_name=Fantasy Focus | format = [[Fantasy Sports]] [[Talk show|talk]] | runtime = 1 hour | starring = [[Jeff Erickson]]
[[John Sickels]] | country = {{flagicon|United States}} [[United States|USA]] | home_station = [[XM Radio]] | first_aired = 2005 | last_aired = present }} '''''Fantasy Focus''''' is a one-hour show from [[RotoWire.com]] focused on [[fantasy baseball]] on [[Blogtalkradio]]. It runs Monday through Friday at 1 PM ET. It can be heard live on [http://www.blogtalkradio.com/rotowire Blogtalkradio/RotoWire] with podcasts available later at [http://www.rotowire.com/podcast RotoWire.com/podcast]. Fantasy Focus is hosted by Jeff Erickson. From 2005 to 2008 the show ran on [[XM Radio]]'s Home Plate 175 channel.{{cite news |first=Matt |last=Schauf |coauthors= |authorlink= |title=RotoWire’s ‘Fantasy Focus’ Moves to BlogTalkRadio |date=2009-02-15 |publisher=World Sports Technology Inc. |url=http://www.fantasysportsbusiness.com/wordpress/2009/02/14/rotowires-fantasy-focus-moves-to-blogtalkradio/ |work=Fantasy Sports Business |pages= |accessdate=2009-02-17 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217190552/http://www.fantasysportsbusiness.com/wordpress/2009/02/14/rotowires-fantasy-focus-moves-to-blogtalkradio/ |archivedate=2009-02-17 |df= }} [[John Sickels]], RotoWire's minor league expert, had hosted "Fantasy Focus" on XM 175 on Fridays, when it is often called "Down on the Farm," and now makes frequent appearances on the show. ==Frequent guests== * [[Will Carroll]] * [[Brandon Funston]] * [[Ron Shandler]] * [[Joe Sheehan]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Major League Baseball on the radio}} [[Category:Fantasy sports]] [[Category:Baseball culture]] [[Category:Major League Baseball on the radio|Fantasy Focus on Blogtalkradio]] [[Category:Radio programs on XM Radio|Fantasy Focus]]

{{Infobox company | name = Fun-Fair-Positive Soccer | logo = [[File:Fun Fair Positive Logo.png|right]] | type = Non-Profit corporation | foundation = March 1986 | location = Houston, Texas, United States | key_people = Jack Hendrie, Founder/Executive Director | industry = Youth sports (soccer) | products = Seasonal youth soccer programs | homepage = [https://www.ffps.org Official web site] }} '''Fun Fair Positive Soccer (FFPS)''' is a 501(c)3 [[non-profit organization]] located in [[Houston, Texas]]. FFPS promotes non-competitive [[soccer]] in a fun, safe and positive environment .https://www.ffps.org/Welcome.aspx#mission To ensure this, FFPS was designed with special rules and policies to enable equal play for every child in all positions. Founded in 1986 in [[Katy, Texas]], by Jack Hendrie, FFPS believes that every child should be accepted and included without a requirement to try out or perform. ==History== Fun Fair Positive Soccer was founded in 1986 by Jack Hendrie and a group of dedicated parents in Katy, Texas, who believed there was a better way to provide every youth with a positive soccer experience. Rules and procedures were designed to give children the opportunity to play and enjoy soccer without the demands from adults to win or perform. Five-a-side soccer rules were chosen, equal play rules with a unique equal substitution system were designed, balanced teams were instituted, and parent training was set up to ensure that games would be fair and positive. Parents were asked to “behave” and be positive toward their children. In 1995, Jack began expanding FFPS beyond Katy to other areas of Houston. Since then, FFPS has grown to encompass 22 new leagues throughout the Greater Houston area and more than 15,000 players. ==Philosophy== FFPS believes that each child has the desire to play, to be treated with respect and to be safe. The goal is for everyone to be successful: belong to a team, build self-esteem, have positive coaches and be positively involved parents. The FFPS system enables everyone to realize these values.{{citation needed|date=May 2011}} ===Fun=== • [[Five-a-side football|5 a-side soccer]]
• Much ball contact
• Fast to learn
• Very safe rules
• Great exercise ===Fair=== • Equal playing time
• Play every position
• Balanced/coed teams
• No tryouts
• [[Special Needs]] kids included ===Positive=== • Trophy to every player
• Only players keep score
• Positive coaching
• Positive parent education
• Everyone wins ==See also== • [http://local.chron.com/s/TX-Katy/Soccer-Clubs Houston Chronicle]
• [http://www.chron.com/woodlands/sports/article/Fun-Fair-Positive-Soccer-Magnolia-League-3860299.php Houston Chronicle Blog]
• [http://www.sugarlandtx.gov/index.aspx?nid=446 Sugarland League (Sugarland Park and Rec.)]
• [http://www.thewoodlands.com/living/waystoplay/sports.html Woodlands League (The Woodlands, TX)]
• [http://www.hcnonline.com/articles/2008/08/06/east_montgomery/sports/32master_escal.web.txt The Observer - East Montgomery County]
• [http://www.hcnonline.com/articles/2008/10/08/kingwood_observer/sports/40kosports_hisdcal.txt The Observer - Kingwood] ==External links== • [https://www.ffps.org/ www.ffps.org] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Youth soccer in the United States]] [[Category:Children's sport]]

formerly = | footnotes = }} '''The International Range Officers Association (IROA)''' is a part of [[International Practical Shooting Confederation]] with the responsibility to train and certify their own dedicated range officials ([[referee]]s),<ref name="WhatIs"/> who are responsible for conducting matches [[Gun safety|safely]], fair and according to the rules. In addition, each IPSC region have their own National Range Officers Institute (NROI) under the IROA.
[[File:Stage brief at the 2017 IPSC Rifle World Shoot.jpg|thumb|right|A squad of shooters get their stage brief by an IROA Range Officer on stage 11 of the [[2017 IPSC Rifle World Shoot]] in Russia.]]
In matches, range officials from IROA and NROI can work alongside in the ranks:
* '''Range Officer (RO)''' - The Range Officer gives the competitors stage briefings, issue range commands and follows the competitor through the conduction of the stage to monitor time, scores and safe firearms handling. * '''Chief Range Officer (CRO)''' - In case there are several Range Officers, a Chief Range Officer will be assigned to have the primary authority over the particular course. Like the RO, the CRO will oversee fair and consistent application of the rules. * '''Range Master (RM)''' - The Range Master has the overall authority over the [[Shooting range|entire range]] during the match, including all Match Officials and the overall safety.
== See also == * [[Shot timer]] * [[Scoring gauge]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Korean name|[[Chung (Korean name)|Jong]]}} {{Infobox football biography |name = Jong Tae-se
정대세 |image = Jong Tae-Se.jpg |image_size = 280px |caption = Jong Tae-se at the match of [[North Korea national football team|North Korea]] against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] at the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] in [[Ellis Park Stadium]]. |fullname = Jong Tae-se (South Korea)
Jong Tae Se (North Korea)http://img.etoday.co.kr/pto_db/2012/06/20120605071547_203586_500_558.jpg
Chong Tese (Japan) |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1984|3|2|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Nagoya]], [[Aichi Prefecture|Aichi]], [[Japan]] |height = {{height|m=1.81}} |position = [[Forward (association football)|Striker]] |currentclub = [[Shimizu S-Pulse]] |clubnumber = 9 |youthyears1 = 1997–1999 | youthclubs1 = Toshun Korean Middle School |youthyears2 = 1999–2002 | youthclubs2 = [[Aichi Korean High School]] |youthyears3 = 2002–2005 | youthclubs3 = [[Korea University (Japan)]] |years1 = 2006–2010 | clubs1 = [[Kawasaki Frontale]] |caps1 = 112 |goals1 = 46 |years2 = 2010–2012 |clubs2 = [[VfL Bochum]] |caps2 = 39 |goals2 = 14 |years3 = 2012–2013 |clubs3 = [[1. FC Köln]] |caps3 = 10 |goals3 = 0 |years4 = 2013–2015 |clubs4 = [[Suwon Samsung Bluewings|Suwon Bluewings]] |caps4 = 72 |goals4 = 23 |years5 = 2015– |clubs5 = [[Shimizu S-Pulse]] |caps5 = 73 |goals5 = 40 |nationalyears1 = 2007–2014 |nationalteam1 = [[North Korea national football team|North Korea]] |nationalcaps1 = 33 |nationalgoals1 = 15 |pcupdate = 22 February 2018 |ntupdate = 15 November 2011 }} {{Infobox Korean name |title=[[Korean name]] |tablewidth=280 |color=lightsteelblue |context=north |hangul=정대세 |hanja=鄭大世 |rr=Jeong Dae-se |mr=Chŏng Tae-se }} '''Jong Tae-se''' (romanization used by [[FIFA]], otherwise spelled as {{Nihongo|'''Chong Tese'''|鄭大世; チョン・テセ}} in [[J-League|Japan]] and [[2. Fußball-Bundesliga|Germany]]; [[hangul]]: 정대세, [[hanja]]: 鄭大世; {{Birth date|df=yes|1984|3|2||}}) is a [[Koreans in Japan|Japanese-born]] [[North Korea]]n [[Association football|football]]er, being one of a few North Koreans mainly played in the Japanese [[J-League]] or the German [[2. Fußball-Bundesliga|2. Bundesliga]]. He is most remembered for his key performance at [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] representing the [[North Korea national football team|North Korea national team]]. He is currently playing for and is the [[Captain (association football)|Captain]] of [[Shimizu S-Pulse]]. ==Early life== Jong was born in [[Nagoya]], [[Japan]] to Korean parents [[Koreans in Japan|residing in Japan]]. Although some reports indicate that Jong's parents and Jong himself have [[South Korean nationality law|South Korean citizenship]], Jong has said that he is not [[South Korea]]n, but [[North Korea]]n as his family identify themselves as North Koreans.{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/may/30/jong-tae-se-north-korea-wayne-rooney/ | title = Jong Tae-se is North Korea's answer to Wayne Rooney | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | date = 11 February 2010 | accessdate = 20 June 2012}} His mother sent him to attend a private school in Japan run by [[Chongryon]], a group closely tied to the North Korean government{{cite web | url = http://goal.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/02/11/north-koreas-wayne-rooney/ | title = North Korea’s Wayne Rooney | publisher = [[New York Times]] | date = 11 February 2010 | accessdate = 18 February 2012}} – where he started football at its elementary school club. He later attended [[Korea University (Japan)|Korea University]], a private university in [[Tokyo]] also funded by [[Chongryon]]. Chongryon, North Korea's de facto embassy in Japan, issued a North Korean passport to him. This made him eligible, per [[FIFA]] rules, to play for North Korea and resulted in ''de facto ''[[dual nationality]]. Jong is fluent in [[Korean Language|Korean]] and [[Japanese Language|Japanese]]. He also knows how to speak [[Portuguese Language|Portuguese]] which he learned from his Brazilian teammates at Japan's Kawasaki Frontale. He also speaks [[German Language|German]] from playing in [[Germany]]. He speaks cursory English, due to his trial in Blackburn.{{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d-pXhNxP2Pg | title = Jong Tae-Se habla portugues y promete lucha a Brasil en el mundial 2010.flv | publisher = maurimc | date = 15 June 2010 | accessdate = 3 July 2012}} Jong publicly emphasized the separation between [[sportsmanship]] and [[politics]] after the disputes before and during the match between North Korea and Japan on 15 November 2011.{{cite news | first = Ji-ho (지호) | last = Lee (이) | script-title=ko:정대세, "北, 정치와 스포츠 구분해야" | date = 18 November 2011 | url = http://www.jpnews.kr/sub_read.html?uid=12056§ion=sc1 | work = JPNews | accessdate =19 November 2011 | language = Korean}} ==Club career== After joining [[Kawasaki Frontale]] in 2006, the striker quickly rose to become one of Kawasaki's best players and one of the best strikers in the [[J-League]].{{cite news| title=Jong Tae-se is North Korea's answer to Wayne Rooney | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/may/30/jong-tae-se-north-korea-wayne-rooney | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | location=London | first=John | last=Duerden | date=30 May 2010 | accessdate = 18 February 2012}} Jong went for a trial with English club [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] in early 2010.{{cite web | url = http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2890/world-cup-2010/2010/06/16/1978951/introducing-the-crying-north-korean-the-peoples-rooney-the | title = Introducing the crying North Korean, the 'Peoples' Rooney', the Blackburn nearly-man: Jong Tae-se | first = Zack | last = Wilson | publisher = Goal.com | date = 16 June 2010 | accessdate = 18 February 2012}} After the 2010 World Cup, Jong joined [[Germany|German]] club [[VfL Bochum]].{{Cite web | title = Bochum holt Jong Tae Se, neuer Gerichtstermin für Boateng | language=German | date = 9 July 2010 | accessdate = 18 February 2012 | publisher = Spiegel Online |url= http://www.spiegel.de/sport/fussball/0,1518,705702,00.html }} After one and half seasons in the [[2. Fußball-Bundesliga|2. Bundesliga]], Jong transferred to [[1. FC Köln]] in the [[Fußball-Bundesliga|1. Bundesliga]] in January 2012, following an injury to German international [[Lukas Podolski]].{{cite web|title=Chong Tese springt für Podolski ein|trans-title=Jong Tae-Se jumps in for Podolski|language=German|date=30 January 2012|accessdate=30 January 2012|publisher=[[Kicker (sports magazine)|kicker]]|url=http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/bundesliga/startseite/564012/artikel_chong-tese-springt-fuer-podolski-ein.html}} However, his time at 1. FC Köln was marred by a lack of playing time. On 3 January 2013, Jong announced that after he would start playing for the first-division South Korean K-League club, [[Suwon Samsung Bluewings]]. He had expressed interest in the move for several months before the announcement, and the Bluewings and [[Ulsan Hyundai FC]] had both been negotiating with him. Jong joined the South Korean outfit on 10 January 2013 for a reported fee of €300,000 from 1. FC Köln.{{cite web | url = http://givemegoal.com/np/2013/01/10/suwon-bluewings-lands-jong-tae-se/ | title = Jong Tae-Se Joins Suwon Bluewings from FC koln | publisher = givemegoal.com | date = 10 January 2013 | accessdate = 13 March 2013}} After deliberation by [[K League 1]] and [[FIFA]] authorities, Jong was registered as a [[South Korea]]n (domestic) player in the K-League and [[AFC Champions League]] competitions.{{cite web | url = http://japanese.joins.com/article/807/167807.html?servcode=600§code=610 | script-title=ja:＜サッカー＞"人民ルーニー"鄭大世、韓国国籍でＣＬ出場 | language = Japanese | publisher = japanese.joins.com | date = 1 February 2013 | accessdate = 25 August 2013}} On 6 April, he scored his debut goal for Suwon in a 3–1 home win against [[Daegu FC]].{{cite web|trans-title=The first goal of Jung Tae Sea | title = '첫 승 실패' 서울, 5G 무승, 포항은 5G 무패... 정대세 첫 골(종합) |url=http://osen.mt.co.kr/article/G1109570701 | language = Korean | publisher= Osen |date = 6 April 2013 | accessdate = 25 August 2013}} Two weeks later, 20 April, he scored a hat-trick in a 4–1 win at [[Daejeon Citizen FC|Daejeon Citizen]].{{cite web|trans-title=[Classic round 8]' Jong Tae-se scored a hat-trick' Suwon wins a come-from-behind victory | title = [클래식 8R] ‘정대세 해트트릭’ 수원, 대전에 4-1 역전승 |url=http://sports.news.naver.com/sports/index.nhn?category=soccer&ctg=news&mod=read&office_id=413&article_id=0000003040 | language = Korean | publisher = sports.news.naver.com | date = 20 April 2013 | accessdate = 25 August 2013}} On 8 July 2015 he was bought by [[Shimizu S-Pulse]] as an emergency signing as Shimizu were in the drop zone after total points calculation from both stages of the season. He was inserted into the starting lineup on 25 July, Matchday 4 of the 2nd stage, away to his former club [[Kawasaki Frontale]] which ended in a 2–3 defeat. ==International career== Jong's first international appearance was on 19 June 2007, during a [[2008 East Asian Football Championship#Group A|2008 East Asian Football Championship qualifier]] match against [[Mongolia national football team|Mongolia]] and he scored his first international goal in that game. He went on to score a total of four goals which Korea DPR won the match 7–0. Jong also played at the 2008 East Asian Football Championship and scored two goals in three matches for Korea DPR, receiving top scorer honors along with [[Park Chu-Young]], [[Yeom Ki-Hun]] and [[Koji Yamase]]. Before [[FIFA 2010 World Cup]] Jong was also the key figure in Korea DPR's [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)|2010 FIFA World Cup qualification]] campaign, as they qualified for the World Cup South Africa for the first time in 44 years. Jong had made himself famous for sobbing uncontrollably when [[Aegukka|the North Korean national anthem]] was played before the kickoff of Korea DPR's first group stage match at the 2010 FIFA World Cup in South Africa, against Brazil.{{cite web | first = Steve | last = Anglesey | url = http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/opinion/blogs/2010-world-cup-blog/World-Cup-2010-team-profile-10-weird-facts-about-North-Korea-including-Kim-Jong-Il-Kim-Jong-Hun-Jong-Tae-Se-and-more-article439739.html | title = Weird World Cup: 10 amazing facts about North Korea | publisher = The Mirror | date = 26 May 2010 | accessdate = 18 February 2012}} In that match he assisted [[Ji Yun-Nam]]'s goal in a 2–1 defeat.{{Cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2890/world-cup-2010/2010/06/15/1978503/world-cup-2010-player-ratings-brazil-21-north-korea|title=World Cup 2010 Player Ratings: Brazil 2–1 North Korea|last=Bairner|first=Robin|date=1 June 2010|publisher=goal.com|accessdate=16 June 2010}} Although [[nickname]]d "the People's [[Wayne Rooney|Rooney]]" by the English press,{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/jun/15/brazil-north-korea-world-cup-match-report|title=World Cup 2010: Brazil find finishing touch to edge out North Korea|last=Ingle|first=Sean|date=1 June 2010|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|accessdate=16 June 2010}} he likened his style of play to [[Didier Drogba]].{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/SPORT/football/06/08/north.korea.secret.team/index.html|title=The secret machine: Inside North Korea's World Cup squad|first=James|last=Montague|publisher=CNN|date=15 June 2010|accessdate=12 December 2017}} ==Club statistics== ''Updated to 22 February 2018''.Nippon Sports Kikaku Publishing inc./日本スポーツ企画出版社, {{Infobox film | name = Kid Galahad | image = Kid Galahad (1937) film poster.jpg | image_size = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Michael Curtiz]] | producer = [[Samuel Bischoff]]
[[Hal B. Wallis]]
[[Jack L. Warner]] | writer = | screenplay = [[Seton I. Miller]] | based on = {{based on|''[[Saturday Evening Post]]''
1936 story|[[Francis Wallace (writer)|Francis Wallace]]}}{{cite journal |date=December 31, 1936 |title=Review: "Kid Galahad" |journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |url=https://variety.com/1936/film/reviews/kid-galahad-1200411404/}} | starring = [[Edward G. Robinson]]
[[Bette Davis]]
[[Humphrey Bogart]] | music = [[Heinz Roemheld]]
[[Max Steiner]]{{cite book|last1=McCarty|first1=Clifford|title=Film composers in America: a filmography, 1911-1970|date=2000|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=0195114736|pages=310–313|edition=2nd}} | cinematography = [[Tony Gaudio]] | editing = [[George Amy]] | distributor = [[Warner Bros.]] | released = {{Film date|1937|05|26|premiere}} | runtime = 102 minutes | country = United States | language = English }} '''''Kid Galahad''''' is a 1937 boxing film starring [[Edward G. Robinson]], [[Bette Davis]], [[Humphrey Bogart]] and, in the title role, rising newcomer [[Wayne Morris (American actor)|Wayne Morris]]. It was scripted by [[Seton I. Miller]] and directed by [[Michael Curtiz]]. It was remade in 1941, this time in a circus setting, as ''[[The Wagons Roll at Night]]'', also with Bogart, and in 1962 as an [[Elvis Presley]] [[Kid Galahad|musical]].{{cite web |url=http://www.timeout.com/london/film/kid-galahad |title=Kid Galahad |publisher=[[Time Out (company)|Time Out]] |accessdate=September 14, 2013}} The original version was re-titled '''''The Battling Bellhop''''' for television distribution in order to avoid confusion with the Presley [[remake]]. ==Plot== In Florida, boxing promoter Nick Donati (Edward G. Robinson) gets doublecrossed by his boxer, who throws a fight for a $25,000 bribe from gangster Turkey Morgan (Humphrey Bogart). Nick and his girlfriend "Fluff" (Bette Davis) decide to throw a wild, days-long party with the money they have left, before looking for a new boxing prospect. Nick orders naive young farmer turned hotel [[bellhop]] Ward Guisenberry ([[Wayne Morris (American actor)|Wayne Morris]]) to mix some drinks, but he does not know how, as he does not drink. Fluff kindly helps him out. When Morgan, underling Buzz Barret ([[Ben Welden]]), and Chuck McGraw ([[William Haade]]), his fighter and new heavyweight champion, arrive uninvited, Ward does not like it when the somewhat drunk McGraw pushes Fluff, so he punches him, knocking him to the ground. Nick is impressed, and persuades him to try boxing. For his first bout, Ward is up against McGraw's experienced brother. Much to everyone's surprise, he wins by knockout. To protect him from Morgan's wrath, Nick sends him, Fluff and ringside assistant Silver Jackson ([[Harry Carey (actor born 1878)|Harry Carey]]) to New York City by train. However, Morgan is waiting outside their usual hotel. He tries to get Ward to sign with him, but Ward knocks him down, insisting he will only sign with Nick. Desperate, Fluff decides to hide the handsome young man at Nick's mother's farm. There he meets Nick's sister, Marie ([[Jane Bryan]]), fresh from a convent education. They clash. When Nick finds out, he is furious. He does not want his family to have anything to do with boxing. He takes Ward back to the city. Ward, rechristened "Kid Galahad", wins a string of fights by knockout. He tells Fluff that his goal is to earn enough to buy a farm. Fluff falls for him, and is crushed when he confides to her that he is in love with Marie. She hides her disappointment, and with her encouragement, he drives up to tell Marie. It turns out that she is just as much in love with him. Fluff leaves Nick, confessing to him that she loves Ward and cannot bear to be around the young man. She gets a job singing in a nightclub. In Ward's next fight, Nick orders him to just box and win on points, as knocking his opponent out would build public pressure to fight the champ too soon; Nick wants more time to train his fighter. However, Morgan tells his foe what to say to infuriate Ward. As a result, Ward wins by knockout. Marie sees the fight; afterward they go out on the town. When she asks to see Fluff, Ward takes her to the nightclub. By coincidence, McGraw is in a private room there, drunk and with a couple of girls. When Morgan shows up to get him, McGraw spots Ward and pushes him to the floor. The two are separated, but Ward offers to fight within the month. Newspaper photographers take pictures of Ward with both Marie and Fluff. As a result, Nick finally learns that Ward has been seeing his sister. Infuriated, Nick secretly turns on his boxer, agreeing to a title bout. He orders Ward to come out slugging, knowing it is a losing strategy. When Morgan discovers that Nick has placed substantial bets against his own fighter, he visits Nick. He learns that Nick wants to get back at Ward, and decides to bet $150,000 himself. During the bout, Ward faithfully follows Nick's orders and is knocked down repeatedly by McGraw. Fluff and Marie attend the fight together. When Fluff realizes what Nick is doing, she and Marie plead with him to stop. Nick finally comes to his senses and changes tactics. In the end, Ward knocks McGraw out and becomes world heavyweight champion. After the fight, an armed Morgan arranges to be alone in the changing room with Nick, Ward and Silver. Nick is prepared though, and also has a gun. They exchange shots, fatal on both sides. Before he dies, Nick gives his blessing to Ward and Marie. ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Edward G. Robinson]] as Nick Donati * [[Bette Davis]] as Louise "Fluff" Phillips * [[Humphrey Bogart]] as Turkey Morgan * [[Wayne Morris (American actor)|Wayne Morris]] as Ward Guisenberry "Kid Galahad" * [[Jane Bryan]] as Marie Donati * [[Harry Carey (actor born 1878)|Harry Carey]] as Silver Jackson * [[William Haade]] as Chuck McGraw * Soledad Jiménez as Mrs. Donati * Joe Cunningham as Joe Taylor, a reporter * [[Ben Welden]] as Buzz Barett * [[Joseph Crehan]] as Brady * [[Veda Ann Borg]] as The Redhead * [[Frank Faylen]] as Barney * Harland Tucker as Gunman * Bob Evans as Sam * Hank Hankinson as Burke * Bob Nestell as O'Brien * Jack Kranz as Denbaugh * George Blake as Referee {{div col end}} ==Production== According to his ''New York Times'' obituary of December 3, 1975, the playwright and screenwriter [[Lawrence Riley]], famous for his Broadway hit ''[[Personal Appearance]]'' (basis of [[Mae West]]'s ''[[Go West, Young Man]]),'' contributed to ''Kid Galahad'''s screenplay, although uncredited. ==Reception== ''[[The New York Times]]'' reviewer [[Frank S. Nugent]] applauded Morris's "natural and easy performance.{{cite news |title=' Kid Galahad,' a Crisp Prize-Ring Film, Comes to the Strand and, With It, a New Star, Wayne Morris |author=Frank S. Nugent |newspaper=The New York Times |date=May 27, 1937 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1937/05/27/archives/the-screen-kid-galahad-a-crisp-prizering-film-comes-to-the-strand-a.html}} [[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]] considered the film a "none too subtle exposition of the now well-worn theme of corruption in the boxing-ring", but conceded that "sleek direction and excellent performances keep it enjoyable." [[Dave Kehr]] of the ''[[Chicago Reader]]'' disagreed, characterizing it as "pretty much all genre and no nuance", though he found Curtiz's direction "surprising soft and light."{{cite news |title=Kid Galahad |author=Dave Kehr |newspaper=Chicago Reader |url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/kid-galahad/Film?oid=1151404}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0029080|title=Kid Galahad}} * {{tcmdb title|id=17865|title=Kid Galahad}} * {{Amg movie|27183|Kid Galahad}} * {{AFI film|id=4886|title=Kid Galahad}} {{Michael Curtiz |state=collapsed}} [[Category:1937 films]] [[Category:1930s crime films]] [[Category:1930s sports films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American crime films]] [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:Boxing films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films based on short fiction]] [[Category:Films directed by Michael Curtiz]] [[Category:Films set in New York City]] [[Category:Warner Bros. films]] [[Category:Films produced by Hal B. Wallis]] [[Category:Films produced by Samuel Bischoff]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Kungliga tennishallen | nickname = | image = [[Image:Kungl Tennishallen 2015b.jpg|300px]] | fullname = | location = [[Stockholm]], Sweden | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = October 1943 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = [[carpet court]] | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Stockholm Open]] ([[ATP World Tour 250 series|Tennis]]) (1969–present)
[[Davis Cup]] ([[Sweden Davis Cup team|Sweden]] vs [[Czech Republic Davis Cup team|Czechoslovakia]]) ([[1975 Davis Cup|Dec 1975]])
[[Davis Cup]] ([[Sweden Davis Cup team|Sweden]] vs [[Argentina Davis Cup team|Argentina]]) ([[2010 Davis Cup World Group#Sweden vs. Argentina|March 2010]]) | seating_capacity = 5,000 [[tennis]] | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} [[File:Kungl Tennishallen 2015i.jpg|thumb|305px|Indoor view]] '''Kungliga tennishallen''' is a [[tennis]] venue at [[ Lidingövägen]] 75 in [[Stockholm]], Sweden. The stadium was built in October 1943 and has a capacity of 5,000. Kungliga tennishallen, now a hard-court surface, remains the venue for the men's [[Stockholm Open]] tournament which was first held in 1969. In 1975 the venue was the host of the year-end [[1975 Commercial Union Assurance Masters|Masters tennis tournament]] as well as the [[1975 Davis Cup|Davis Cup]] final between [[Sweden Davis Cup team|Sweden]] and [[Czech Republic Davis Cup team|Czechoslovakia]].{{cite web|title=1975 Davis Cup Finals|url=https://www.daviscup.com/en/draws-results/tie.aspx?id=M-DC-1975-WG-M-SWE-TCH-01|website=[[Davis Cup]]|publisher=[[International Tennis Federation]] (ITF)}} ==Other activities== The [[Volvo PV444/544]] was launched at the Kungliga tennishallen in September 1944.{{cite web|title=Lidingövägen 75, Kungliga Tennishallen|url=https://stockholmskallan.stockholm.se/post/9983|website=Stockholmskällan}} It was the site on 15 April 1962 of the fight between former world heavyweight boxing champion [[Ingemar Johansson]] and Dutch champion Wim Snoek. Various music concerts have been held at Kungliga including [[Louis Armstrong]], [[David Bowie]], the [[Beatles]] and the [[Rolling Stones]]. ==See also== * [[List of tennis stadiums by capacity]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.kltk.se/ Kungliga Lawn-tennisklubben] * [http://wikimapia.org/#lat=59.350499&lon=18.0946326&z=17&l=0&m=b&v=8 Wikimapia] * [http://lh5.ggpht.com/_2-4zvrrn4zQ/R-pMb0ujDCI/AAAAAAAAA9o/-oFjItby4oM/STP60016.JPG Kungliga tennishallen imagine int] * [http://lh5.ggpht.com/_2-4zvrrn4zQ/R-pMZ0ujDBI/AAAAAAAAA9g/cbSIDlL9S3o/STP60014.JPG Kungliga tennishallen] * [http://farm1.static.flickr.com/109/274147099_46837a6056_o.jpg Kungliga tennishallen 2006] * [http://farm1.static.flickr.com/94/274147017_df4b486102_o.jpg Kungliga tennishallen 2006 imagine 2] {{coord|59|21|01|N|18|05|43|E|display=title|region:SE_type:landmark}} {{s-start}} {{Succession box| title=[[ATP World Tour Finals|Masters Cup]]

The '''[[Major Indoor Soccer League (2001–08)|Major Indoor Soccer League]]''' '''(MISL)''' was the top professional [[indoor soccer]] league in the USA. The league was a member of both the [[United States Soccer Federation]] and [[FIFA]]. The MISL replaced the '''[[National Professional Soccer League II|NPSL]]''' which folded in 2001. This version of the MISL recognizes NPSL history which dates back to 1984 when the NPSL was started as the '''[[National Professional Soccer League II|AISA]]'''. revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | name = Mediolanum Forum | nickname = | image = Forum_Assago_Parquet_2.jpg | image_size = 250px | image_alt = | logo_image = Mediolanum Forum logo.png | caption = The central arena during the Euroleague Final Four (c.2014) | fullname = Mediolanum Forum di Assago | location = [[Milan metropolitan area|Grande Milano]] | address = Via Giuseppe di Vittorio 6
20090 [[Assago]] [[Metropolitan City of Milan|MI]] [[Italy]] | coordinates = {{coord|45|24|4|N|9|8|32|E|type:landmark_region:IT|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1988 | built = | opened = 26 October 1990 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = ForumNet Group | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Forum di Assago (1990–97)
FilaForum (1997–2006)
DatchForum (2006–08) | tenants = [[Pallacanestro Olimpia Milano]] {{small|([[Lega Basket Serie A|LBA]]) (1990–present)}} | capacity = 12,700 | dimensions = | scoreboard = | website = {{URL|http://www.mediolanumforum.it|Venue Website}} }} The '''Mediolanum Forum''' (originally the '''Forum di Assago''', formerly the '''FilaForum''', '''DatchForum''') is an [[indoor arena|indoor sports arena]] that is located in [[Assago]], near [[Milan]], Italy. The arena has a seating capacity of 12,700[http://www.mediolanumforum.it/it/chisiamo/ CHI SIAMO {{it icon}}.] and is primarily used for [[ice hockey]], [[basketball]], [[tennis]] & live concerts. The venue is the home ground of the [[Lega Basket Serie A|Italian League]] professional basketball team [[Pallacanestro Olimpia Milano]]. The Forum received the European Prize for Architecture for sports venues awarded by [[CONI]] and the Council of Europe. It is also one of two facilities in Italy, along with [[PalaLottomatica]] in Rome, to be part of the ''European Arenas Association'' network.[http://www.mediolanumforum.it/it/chisiamo/ MediolanumForumn.it Chi Siamo.] In January 2009, the arena changed its name to the current name of [[Mediolanum (company)|Mediolanum]] Forum, replacing the old name of DatchForum.[http://www.numeroventi.com/2009/01/08/il-datchforum-cambia-nome-nasce-il-mediolanum-forum/ Numeroventi.com Il Datchforum cambia nome, nasce il MEDIOLANUM FORUM {{it icon}}.] == Entertainment events == {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" |- ! colspan="3"|Entertainment events at Mediolanum Forum |- ! width=50| Date ! width=100| Artists ! width=150| Events |- style="background:#ddd;" ! colspan="3"|'''1993''' |- | February 18 | rowspan=2| [[Paul McCartney]] | rowspan=2| [[The New World Tour]] |- | February 19 |- | May 5 | [[Iron Maiden]] | [[Real Live Tour]] |- |- style="background:#ddd;" ! colspan="3"|'''1996''' |- | September 19 | [[Tina Turner]] | [[Wildest Dreams Tour]] |- | November 13 | [[Pearl Jam]] | [[No Code Tour]] |- style="background:#ddd;" ! colspan="3"|'''1998''' |- | March 8-9 | [[Spice Girls]] | [[Spiceworld Tour]] |- style="background:#ddd;" ! colspan="3"|'''1999''' |- | May 5 | [[Janet Jackson]] | [[The Velvet Rope Tour]] |- style="background:#ddd;" ! colspan="3"|'''1999''' |- | June 23 | [[Alanis Morissette]] | [[Junkie Tour]] |- | September 23 | [[Iron Maiden]] | [[The Ed Hunter Tour]] |- style="background:#ddd;" ! colspan="4"|'''2000''' |- | February 17 | [[Mariah Carey]] | [[Rainbow World Tour]] |- | June 13 | rowspan=3| [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] | rowspan=3| [[Drowned World Tour]] |- | June 14 |- | June 15 |- | June 22 | [[Pearl Jam]] | [[Binaural Tour]] |- | October 24 | [[Britney Spears]] | [[Oops!... [[Shakira]] | [[El Dorado World Tour]] |- | June 25 | [[Queen (band)|Queen]] | [[Queen + Adam Lambert]] |} ==Sports== The arena hosted the [[1994 Men's World Ice Hockey Championships]], the 2003 [[IIHF Continental Cup]] Superfinal of [[ice hockey]] (together with [[Lugano]]'s [[Pista La Resega]]), [[WWE Raw]] and [[WWE SmackDown]] in 2007, and the [[2009 World Amateur Boxing Championships]]. Since 2011, the Forum has also been home to [[La Grande Sfida]], the annual tennis exhibition event played every Christmas. The arena also hosted the [[2013–14 Euroleague|2014]] edition of the [[EuroLeague Final Four]][http://www.euroleague.net/news/i/114714/180 Euroleague.net Milan, Italy to host 2014 Turkish Airlines Euroleague Final Four.] and, in the same year, the finals of the 2014 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship. Also, some matches of the [[2018 FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship|FIVB Volleyball World Championship]] are scheduled to be held at the venue. ==Gallery== image:Forum Assago Parquet 3.jpg|

{{Football club infobox | clubname = Mundu SC| image = | fullname = Mundu Sport Club| nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Unguja Park]]
[[Unguja]], [[Zanzibar]] ([[Tanzania]])| capacity = 5,000| chairman = {{flagicon|Zanzibar}}| manager = {{flagicon|Zanzibar}}| league = [[Zanzibar Premier League]] | season = 2013 | position = || }} '''Mundu SC''' is a [[Zanzibar]] [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Nungwi]] near [[Unguja]] in [[East Africa]]. The club is one of the three biggest football clubs in [[Unguja]]. Currently the team competes in the [[Zanzibar Premier League]]. The club competed in the [[CAF Confederation Cup]] for the first time in 2007.http://scoreshelf.com/rmgb/en/Mundu_SC/CAF_Confederation_Cup Profile ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 5000 capacity [[Unguja Park]]. ==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[CAF Confederation Cup]]: 2 appearances''' :2007,2009 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://scoreshelf.com/rmgb/en/Mundu_SC/CAF_Confederation_Cup Scoreshelf] *[http://www.footballdatabase.eu/football.club.mundu-sc..8297..en.html FootballDatabase] *[http://www.calciozz.it/equipa.php?id=27743&epoca_id=0 Calciozz] {{Tanzania-footyclub-stub}} {{Zanzibar-footyclub-stub}} [[Category:Football clubs in Tanzania]] [[Category:Zanzibari football clubs]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Ménfői úti Stadion | nickname = Alcufer | logo_image = | image = | caption = | fullname = Ménfői úti Stadion | location = [[Győr]], Hungary | coordinates = | broke_ground = 2014 | built = 2014-15 | opened = 22 September 2015 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Gyirmót SE]] | operator = | surface = Grass
Field | construction_cost = c. 900 million [[Hungarian forint|HUF]] | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Gyirmót SE]] | seating_capacity = 4,500 | suites = 10 [[Skybox (sports)|skybox]] | record_attendance = 4,000 (Gyirmót vs Dunaújváros, 11 September 2015) | dimensions = {{convert|105|x|68|m|ft|abbr=on}} | website = [http://www.gyirmotfc.hu/index.php?ugras=statikus&statoldal=1500 www.gyimrotfc.hu] }} '''Ménfői úti Stadion''' or '''Alcufer Stadion''' is a sports venue in Gyirmót, a district of [[Győr]], [[Hungary]]. The stadium is home to the [[association football]] side [[Gyirmót SE]]. The stadium has a capacity of 4,500.http://www.gyirmotfc.hu/index.php?ugras=statikus&statoldal=1500 ==History== On 22 September 2015, the stadium was opened. The first match was played against [[Dunaújváros PASE]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nemzetisport.hu/labdarugo_nb_ii/nb-ii-szombaton-stadionavato-nyitja-kapuit-az-alcufer-2439551|title=NB II: szombaton stadionavató, nyitja kapuit az Alcufer|date=22 September 2015|publisher=[[Nemzeti Sport]]}} On 25 March 2016, the first international match was played at the stadium. [[Hungary national under-21 football team|Hungary]] (U-21) hosted [[Israel national under-21 football team|Israel]] (U-21) in the [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification Group 4]] match. The final results was a goalless draw.{{cite web|url=http://www.nemzetisport.hu/magyar_valogatott/u21-es-valogatott-magyarorszag-izrael-2491357|title=Magyarország (U-21) 0-0 Izrael (U-21)|date=25 March 2016|publisher=[[Nemzeti Sport]]}} ==Cost== The cost of the construction was 900 million HUF.{{cite web|url=http://www.nemzetisport.hu/labdarugo_nb_ii/nb-ii-906-milliobol-ujul-meg-a-gyirmot-stadionja-2392221|title=NB II: 906 millióból újul meg a Gyirmót stadionja|date=2 February 2015|publisher=[[Nemzeti Sport]]}} ==Milestone matches== {{football box collapsible |date = 24 March 2016 |team1 = [[Hungary national under-21 football team|Hungary]] (U-21) {{flagicon|Hungary}} |score = 0–0 |report = [http://www.nemzetisport.hu/magyar_valogatott/u21-es-valogatott-magyarorszag-izrael-2491357 Report] |team2 = {{flagicon|Israel}} [[Israel national under-21 football team|Israel]] (U-21) |goals1 = |goals2 = |stadium = [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification Group 4|2017 UEFA U-21 qualification]]
(First international match)| attendance = 800 | |referee = Thorarinsson ([[Iceland Football Association|Iceland]])}} {{football box collapsible |date = 7 July 2016 |team1 = [[MTK Budapest FC|MTK Budapest]] {{flagicon|Hungary}} |score = 2–0 |report = [http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2017/matches/round=2000788/match=2020063/prematch/player-lists/index.html Report] |team2 = {{flagicon|Kazakhstan}} [[FC Aktobe|Aktobe]] |goals1 = |goals2 = |stadium = [[2016-17 UEFA Europa League]]
