[[Davis Cup]] ([[Australia Davis Cup team|Australia]] vs [[United States Davis Cup team|USA]]) ([[2017 Davis Cup World Group|April 2017]]) | seating_capacity = 5,500
(extra temporary 7,000) | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} '''Queensland Tennis Centre''', known during its development as the Tennyson Tennis Centre,{{cite news | title =Your first view of the Tennyson Tennis Centre| work = | publisher =brisbane times | date = | url =http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/ftimages/2007/06/03/1180809312141.html| accessdate = 2009-11-25}} is a [[tennis]] venue in [[Tennyson, Queensland|Tennyson]], [[Brisbane]], [[Australia]]. It is an [[Australian dollar|A$]]82 million state-of-the-art tennis facility opened on 2 January 2009{{cite news | title =Queensland Tennis Centre | work = | publisher =Department of Public Works | date = | url =http://www.publicworks.qld.gov.au/majorprojects/Pages/QldTennisCentre.aspx | accessdate =2009-11-25 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20090516064232/http://www.publicworks.qld.gov.au/majorprojects/Pages/QldTennisCentre.aspx | archivedate =2009-05-16 | df = }} at the site of the demolished [[Tennyson Power Station]]. It was designed by internationally recognised stadium designers [[HOK Sport Venue Event]] and The Mirvac Group's in-house architectural practice, HPA Pty Ltd{{cite news | title =QLD Tennis Centre | work = | publisher =Tennis Australia | date = | url =http://www.tennis.com.au/pages/default.aspx?id=21&pageId=12355 | accessdate =2009-11-25 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20091027211808/http://www.tennis.com.au/pages/default.aspx?id=21&pageId=12355 | archivedate =2009-10-27 | df = }} and constructed by [[Mirvac]] as part of the Tennyson Riverside development. The main court was designed to incorporate a [[Polytetrafluoroethylene|PTFE]] glass fibre [[fabric structure|fabric roof]]. This [[tensile membrane structure]] allows diffused light through into the arena reducing the need for artificial lighting. The light weight of the fabric also reduced the amount of steel required and saved on building costs. Brisbane-based company [[Taiyo Membrane Corporation]] supplied and installed this roof along with other smaller outdoor structures at this venue. It has twenty-three International Tennis Federation standard [[tennis court]]s, including the centre court and two showcase courts, representing all playing surfaces ([[hardcourt]], clay and grass). The centre court ''Pat Rafter Arena'',[http://www.brisbaneinternational.com.au/2008/10/stadium-named-after-pat-rafter Stadium named after Pat Rafter] named in honour of the Australian tennis player [[Patrick Rafter]], has a [[seating capacity]] of 5,500 (with an extra temporary seating of 1,500 bringing total capacity to 7,000). Since January 2009 the Queensland Tennis Centre has been the host centre for combined men and women's international [[tennis]] tournament entitled the [[Brisbane International]], a combination of the former [[Next Generation Adelaide International]] event in Adelaide and the Mondial Gold Coast Women's championships.{{cite news| title =Adelaide to merge with Brisbane in '09| work =| publisher =Tennis Australia| date =| url =http://www.tennisaustralia.com.au/pages/article.aspx?id=4&articleid=ArticleID2006121112597&pageId=11635&HandlerId=1| accessdate =2009-11-26| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070901200512/http://www.tennisaustralia.com.au/pages/article.aspx?id=4&articleid=ArticleID2006121112597&pageId=11635&HandlerId=1| archivedate =2007-09-01| df =}} ==See also== {{Portal|Brisbane|Tennis}} * [[List of tennis stadiums by capacity]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.queenslandtenniscentre.com.au/ Official webpage of Queensland Tennis Centre] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070829035749/http://www.tennisattennyson.com.au/images/centre_court_view.jpg View of Centre Court] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110706112429/http://www.tennisattennyson.com.au/prop_dev.htm Details of Development] *[http://www.tennis.com.au/pages/image.aspx?assetId=RDM39791.6553696065 Where is the Queensland Tennis Centre]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *{{austadiums|322}} *[http://www.daviscup.com/en/results/tie/details.aspx?tieID=100014717 Davis Cup Australia vs Japan Asia/Oceania Group I 2nd Round 7-9 May 2010] *[http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3330/3188687381_48c2ac9aa2_b.jpg Interior image 1] *[http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3408/3186614133_ff11627840_o.jpg Interior image 2] *[http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3314/3186578023_9735c8ffc0_o.jpg Interior image 3] ==Gallery== {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Raymond James Stadium | nickname = "Ray Jay" | logo_image = Raymond James Stadium logo.png | image = Raymond James Stadium02.JPG | location = [[Tampa, Florida]] | coordinates = {{coord|27|58|33|N|82|30|12|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = October 15, 1996{{cite news |title=Patriots Sign Byars|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1MNNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vw4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=3977,4180348&dq=en|newspaper=[[The Ledger]]|date=October 16, 1996|accessdate=October 22, 2011}} | opened = September 20, 1998 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Hillsborough County, Florida|Hillsborough County]] | operator = Tampa Sports Authority | surface = [[Bermuda grass|Tifway 419 Bermuda]] | architect = Wagner Murray Architects
[[Populous (company)|Populous]] (then HOK Sport) | structural engineer = [[Walter P Moore]]
Bliss and Nyitray, Inc. | services engineer = FSC-Inc.{{cite web|url=http://www.fsc-inc.com/PDF/Sports.pdf|title=Sports Facilities - FSC-Inc.|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904162907/http://www.fsc-inc.com/pdf/Sports.pdf|archivedate=September 4, 2012|df=mdy-all}} | general_contractor = Manhattan Construction, Hunt/Metric Joint Venture{{cite web |title=Raymond James Stadium|url=http://football.ballparks.com/NFL/TampaBayBucs/index.htm|publisher=Ballparks.com}} | suites = 195 | record_attendance = {{plainlist| *74,512 (2017 CFP National Championship Game) }} | tenants = [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] ([[National Football League|NFL]]) (1998–present)
[[South Florida Bulls football|South Florida Bulls]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1998–present)
[[Tampa Bay Mutiny]] ([[Major League Soccer|MLS]]) (1999–2001)
[[Outback Bowl]] ([[NCAA]]) (1999–present)
[[Gasparilla Bowl]] ([[NCAA]]) (2017–present) | website = {{official URL}} | address = 4201 N. Dale Mabry Highway | construction_cost = US$168.5 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|168500000|1998}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars){{inflation-fn|US}} | seating_capacity = {{plainlist| * 65,618 (2016–present) (expandable to 75,000) * 65,890 (2013–2015) * 65,856 (2008–2012) * 65,657 (2001–2007) * 66,321 (1998–2000) }} }} '''Raymond James Stadium''', also known as "Ray Jay",{{cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/features/music/u2-fans-line-up-before-dawn-at-ray-jay-stadium/1042679|title=U2 Fans Line Up Before Dawn at Ray Jay Stadium|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|accessdate=November 7, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607190129/http://www.tampabay.com/features/music/u2-fans-line-up-before-dawn-at-ray-jay-stadium/1042679|archive-date=June 7, 2011|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} is a multi-purpose [[American football|football]] stadium located in [[Tampa, Florida]]. It is home to the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL) as well as the [[NCAA]]'s [[South Florida Bulls football team]]. The stadium seats 65,618.{{cite web|url=http://www.raymondjames.com/stadium/faq.htm|title=Raymond James|website=www.raymondjames.com}} With the addition of temporary seating, it can be expanded to 75,000 for special events. Raymond James Stadium hosted [[Super Bowl]]s [[Super Bowl XXXV|XXXV]] and [[Super Bowl XLIII|XLIII]], as well as the [[2017 College Football Playoff National Championship]]. It is also set to host [[Super Bowl LV]] in February 2021. ==History== Raymond James Stadium was built to replace [[Tampa Stadium]] at the demand of the new Bucs owner [[Malcolm Glazer]]. It is located adjacent to the site of the old stadium on the former location of [[Al Lopez Field]], a minor-league baseball stadium that had been demolished in 1989. Once completed, the final cost of the new stadium was $168.5 million, with the entire cost publicly financed.{{cite news |title=Super Bowl 2001: We Paid for It; It Paid Off|first=Jeff|last=Testerman|url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/012501/news_pf/SuperBowl2001/We_paid_for_it_it_pai.shtml|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=January 25, 2001|accessdate=July 28, 2012}} It was known as Tampa Community Stadium during construction, but the [[naming rights]] were bought for US$32.5 million for a 13–year deal by [[St. Petersburg, Florida|St. Petersburg]]-based [[Raymond James Financial]] in June 1998.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/1998/06/27/archive/main12734.shtml?source=search_story|title=Bucs' New Stadium Gets A Name, New name is 'The Raymond James Stadium'|work=CBS News|date=December 13, 1999|accessdate=February 14, 2009}} On April 27, 2006, an extension was signed to maintain naming rights through 2015. In May 2016 the Buccaneers announced that the naming rights were extended an additional 12 years ensuring that Raymond James Financial's name will continue to appear through 2028.{{cite web|url= http://www.buccaneers.com/news/article-1/Buccaneers-Announce-Stadium-Naming-Rights-Extension/071b85fc-44c3-4ad0-9b8e-3bf5b858d167|title=Raymond James Stadium Naming Rights Through 2028|work=buccaneers.com|date=August 28, 2016}} The stadium officially opened on September 20, 1998http://raymondjamesstadium.com/stadium-history/, when the Tampa Bay Buccaneers defeated the [[Chicago Bears]], 27–15. The stadium hosted its first soccer game on March 20, 1999, when the [[Tampa Bay Mutiny]] lost to [[D.C. United]], 5–2. The stadium also hosts the annual [[Outback Bowl]] college football post-season game on [[New Year's Day]] since 1999. The [[Gasparilla Bowl]] will be held at the venue starting with the 2018 edition. The stadium was selected to host the [[ACC Championship Game]] in 2008 and 2009. The stadium is home field for the [[South Florida Bulls football|University of South Florida Bulls]] of the [[American Athletic Conference]]. The team's record crowd at Raymond James Stadium is 69,383, on September 29, 2012, when the Bulls – during their [[2012 South Florida Bulls football team|worst season ever]] – played a non-conference game against the popular [[Florida State Seminoles football|Florida State University Seminoles]] from the powerhouse [[Atlantic Coast Conference]] for the first time. The largest crowd ever recorded in Raymond James Stadium came on January 9, 2017 as the stadium hosted the [[2017 College Football Playoff National Championship]]. 74,512 people were in attendance. Through to the 2009 season, every Buccaneers game at Raymond James Stadium sold out. In 2010, no home game achieved a ticket sell out, so [[National Football League television blackout policies|none could be broadcast on local television]]. The streak carried over until week four of the 2011 season, when it sold enough tickets for its Monday night game with the [[Indianapolis Colts]] on October 3 to avoid a local blackout. The [[Monster Jam]] tour for [[monster truck]]s holds an event at the stadium. ==Features== [[File:pirate ship.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The pirate ship at Raymond James Stadium]] One of the most recognizable features of the stadium is a {{convert|103|ft|m|adj=on}}, 43-ton steel-and-concrete replica pirate ship in the north end zone. Each time the Bucs score points, enter the other team's [[red zone (gridiron football)|red zone]], or win a home game, the replica cannons on the ship are fired off. The cannons fire once for each point scored. In addition, when the Buccaneers enter their opponent's red zone, stadium hosts hoist team [[flag]]s around the perimeter of the upper deck. During various times throughout the game, the song "[[Yo Ho (A Pirate's Life for Me)]]" is played on the stadium public address system (taken from [[Pirates of the Caribbean (theme park ride)|Pirates of the Caribbean]]), which signals patrons on board the ship to throw beads, t–shirts, and other free prizes to the people below. The segment is also known as a "Mini [[José Gaspar|Gasparilla]]" to most fans. An animated parrot sits on the stern of the pirate ship. Controlled by radio and remote control, the parrot picks fans out of the crowd and talks to those passing by.{{cite web|url=http://www.raymondjames.com/stadium/stadium_facts.htm|title=Raymond James Stadium | Stadium Facts|work=Raymondjames.com|accessdate=February 14, 2009}} During [[Super Bowl XXXV]] on [[NFL on CBS|CBS]], the pregame, halftime, and post-game desk reporting took place from aboard the pirate ship. [[Football Night in America|NBC]]'s [[Super Bowl XLIII]] and [[ESPN College Football|ESPN]]'s [[2017 College Football Playoff National Championship]] coverage also emanated from the ship. The two "Buc Vision" {{convert|2200|sqft|sqm|adj=on}} [[Daktronics]] video displays were among the largest in the league when they were built. In 2016 they were replaced with 9,600-square foot, high-definition video boards in both end zones. 'Buccaneer Cove' features a weathered, two–story fishing village [[facade]], housing stadium concessions and [[restroom]]s. All areas of the stadium are [[Americans with Disabilities Act|ADA]] compliant. Temporary [[bleacher]]s were erected in the end zones for [[Super Bowl XXXV]], which set a then-record stadium attendance of 71,921. The stadium attendance record has since been surpassed by the [[2017 College Football Playoff National Championship]], which also made use of temporary seating.{{Cite news|url=https://blog.tickpick.com/college-football-national-championship-seating-chart/|title=College Football National Championship Seating Chart 2017|access-date=2017-03-28|language=en-US}} In [[2003 NFL season|2003]], the corner [[billboards]] in the stadium were replaced with rotating [[trilon]] billboards and these were replaced in 2016 with new high visibility displays. Raymond James Stadium boasts the second-best turf in the NFL, according to a 2009 biannual players' survey.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=nfl&id=3870554|title=Top Turf in the NFL? Cards Best, Steelers Worst|work=ESPN.com|date=January 29, 2009|accessdate=February 18, 2012}} In early 2016, the stadium was given an extensive facelift. The most notable improvement was the replacement of the {{convert|2200|sqft|sqm|adj=on}} video displays with state of the art, high visibility {{convert|9600|sqft|sqm|adj=on}} video displays in both the north and south end zones along with the addition of a new {{convert|2300|sqft|sqm|adj=on}} video tower in each corner. All together, the video displays cover more than {{convert|28,000|sqft|sqm|adj=on}}, making Raymond James Stadium the third-largest video displays in the NFL. The original sound system and the stadium's luxury boxes were also upgraded.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/blog/tampa-bay-buccaneers/post/_/id/13835/bucs-raymond-james-stadium-unveils-first-portion-of-140m-makeover|title=Raymond James Stadium gets $140M Makeover|work=ESPN.com|date=August 28, 2016}} A second round of improvements are planned for after the 2016 season is complete. ==Nicknames== The stadium is referred to as "Ray Jay" or "The New Sombrero", a spinoff from "The Big Sombrero", the nickname of [[Tampa Stadium]]. Somewhat derisively, it has been occasionally referred to as "the CITS", a name coined by long-time local sportscaster Chris Thomas which stands for "Community Investment Tax Stadium", referring to the fact that the stadium was entirely financed by local taxpayers.{{cite news |title=Chris Thomas Touched Us All|first=Eric|last=Deggans|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2004/02/20/Sports/_Chris_Thomas_touched.shtml|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=February 20, 2004|accessdate=July 28, 2012}} ==Timeline== [[File:Raymondjames2005.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Buccaneer game action at Raymond James Stadium]] * Immediately upon purchasing the Bucs in 1995, new owner [[Malcolm Glazer]] declared [[Tampa Stadium]] inadequate and began lobbying local government for a replacement.{{cite news |title=Bucs Stay in Tampa With a Big Price Tag|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4207/is_19950117/ai_n10181431|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081227174157/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4207/is_19950117/ai_n10181431|dead-url=yes|archive-date=December 27, 2008|newspaper=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|Milwaukee Journal]]|date=January 17, 1995|accessdate=February 14, 2009}} When the community did not move quickly enough to suit the Glazer family, the new owners openly contacted several other cities around the U.S. about possible relocation.{{cite news |first=Chareen|last=Williams|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1995-12-07/sports/9512061680_1_tampa-bay-buccaneers-joel-glazer-cleveland|title=Tampa Still Hopeful Bucs Will Stay Put|newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|date=December 7, 1995|accessdate=July 28, 2012}} * The city of Tampa and Hillsborough County came up with a plan to fund a new stadium as part of a "Community Investment Tax", which was voted on in a [[referendum]] in September 1996. As part of the campaign to pass the referendum, Glazer promised to pay half the cost of the new stadium if fans put down 50,000 deposits on 10–year [[season ticket]] commitments. The drive fell 17,000 deposits short, the offer was withdrawn, and the Bucs did not pay any of the stadium's construction cost.{{cite news |title=Fantastic Voyage|first=Chris|last=Harry|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2005-07-24/sports/GLAZERS24A_1_joel-glazer-malcolm-glazer-bryan-glazer|newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|date=July 24, 2005|accessdate=July 28, 2012}}{{cite news |title=Chipping In: Malcolm Glazer Says He'll Pay "About Half" the Cost of a New Stadium As a Seat-Deposit Plan Is Unveiled|first=Joe|last=Henderson|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=0EB0F5479486B7D2&p_docnum=1&p_queryname=1|newspaper=[[The Tampa Tribune]]|date=September 28, 1995|accessdate=July 28, 2012}} * On September 3, 1996, the voters of [[Hillsborough County, Florida]] approved, by 53% to 47% margin, a 30-year, half–cent sales tax to build new schools, improve public safety and infrastructure, and to build the Buccaneers a $192 million new stadium entirely with public money.{{cite news |title=Stadium Rose Despite Challenges|first=Wayne|last=Washington|url=http://www.sptimes.com/Sports/RJS/91898/Stadium_rose_despite_.html|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=September 18, 1998|accessdate=July 28, 2012}} The team signed a stadium lease in which the local government must pay for almost all of the stadium expenses while the franchise keeps almost all of the proceeds.{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/business/2007/09/12/biz_07nfl_all_slide_13.html |title=In Pictures: The Most Valuable NFL Teams |work=Forbes.com |date=September 12, 2007 |accessdate=February 14, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011015207/http://www.forbes.com/business/2007/09/12/biz_07nfl_all_slide_13.html |archivedate=October 11, 2008 |df= }} Former Tampa mayor Bill Poe sued to stop the deal, claiming that giving such a "sweetheart deal" to a private business violated [[Florida Constitution|Florida's state constitution]].{{cite news |title=Stadium Tax Helped Pay for Bucs' Success|first=Jeff|last=Testerman|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2003/01/24/TampaBay/Stadium_tax_helped_pa.shtml|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=January 24, 2003|accessdate=July 28, 2012}} A local court agreed with Poe, but the Bucs and local government appealed. Eventually, the [[Supreme Court of Florida]] ruled that the agreement was constitutional, and construction continued as planned.{{cite news |title=Former Mayor's Opinion of Stadium Hasn't Changed|first=Michael|last=Canning|url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/092901/news_pf/TampaBay/Former_mayor_s_opinio.shtml|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=September 29, 2001|accessdate=July 28, 2012}} * On October 31, 1996, the NFL owners met in [[New Orleans]] to select the host site for [[Super Bowl XXXIII]] and [[Super Bowl XXXIV]]. [[Pro Player Stadium]] in the [[Miami]] area was selected to host Super Bowl XXXIII. [[Atlanta]], [[Tempe, Arizona|Tempe]] and Tampa were candidates for Super Bowl XXXIV, with Tampa the favorite, following the successful tax referendum. The [[Georgia Dome]] in Atlanta, however, was awarded the game. As a compromise, Tampa was awarded Super Bowl XXXV, which the NFL had not originally planned to select that day. * The last [[Major League Soccer]] game played at Raymond James Stadium was on September 9, 2001 when the Mutiny lost to the [[Columbus Crew]], 2–1, in front of 9,932 people. Although the [[September 11 attacks]] resulted in the cancellation of the remainder of the [[2001 Major League Soccer season|2001 MLS regular season]], the Mutiny did not have any more home games scheduled anyway. The Mutiny were subsequently disbanded by the league. National-level soccer matches are still occasionally played at Raymond James, as its wide field makes it ideal for hosting soccer. * In April 2003, the Tampa Sports Authority proposed passing ownership of the stadium to Hillsborough County to avoid having to pay millions of dollars in property taxes (The Bucs' lease agreement dictated that they not have to pay property taxes). However, Bucs had a right of refusal and refused to sign off on the plan unless the local government paid more of the cost for game–day security and increased the amount of (county-purchased) insurance coverage for the stadium.{{cite news |title=Tampabay: Tax Bill Swells as Bucs Stall|first=Bill|last=Varian|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2003/04/18/TampaBay/Tax_bill_swells_as_Bu.shtml|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=April 18, 2003|accessdate=February 14, 2009}} The dispute continued for months until December 2003, when the county legally declared the stadium a [[condominium]] and took ownership. As part of the change, the Bucs were given ownership of portions of the structure. To win the Bucs' approval, the county agreed to refund the team's resultant property tax payments annually.{{cite news |title=Hillsborough: Hillsborough Votes Yes on Plan to Own Stadium|first=Bill|last=Varian|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2003/03/06/Hillsborough/Hillsborough_votes_ye.shtml|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=March 6, 2003|accessdate=February 14, 2009}}{{cite news |title=Hillsborough: County Act Ends Tax on Stadium|first=Bill|last=Varian|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2003/12/18/Hillsborough/County_act_ends_tax_o.shtml|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=December 18, 2003|accessdate=February 14, 2009}} * On May 25, 2005, NFL owners met in Washington, D.C. to select the host site for [[Super Bowl XLIII]]. During the balloting, Raymond James Stadium defeated the [[Georgia Dome]] ([[Atlanta]]), [[Reliant Stadium]] ([[Houston]]), and [[Dolphins Stadium]] ([[Miami Gardens, Florida|Miami Gardens]]). * After a nearly two-year legal battle, the Tampa Sports Authority came to a settlement with popular sports-seating and telescopic platform/bleacher company Hussey Seating of [[North Berwick, Maine]]. Following the stadium's opening in 1998, roughly 50,000 Hussey-manufactured seats at Raymond James Stadium began to fade from their original color – a bright, vibrant shade of red – to a shade of washed-out pink. Spotting this obvious defect, the Buccaneers organization pleaded to the TSA to sue the seating manufacturing company for the cost to replace the affected chairs in 2003. Initially, in May 2004, after testing samples of the seats, Hussey Seating did not find any cause for the fading, and thus, found no reason to replace the seats at the company's cost under the current 10–year [[warranty]]. After the TSA cited a portion of the warranty which did, in fact, state that Hussey would replace seats if any fading were to occur, Hussey president Tim Hussey admitted an error in the research and eventually would come to a $1.5 million agreement with the TSA to replace the problem seats. Reportedly, the seat-fading occurred due to a manufacturing error by Hussey, as a [[ultraviolet|UV]] inhibitor – a [[sunscreen]]-like component for the plastic – was forgotten in the mixture used to create the seats. All of the problem seats were replaced by new, non–pink seats in the spring of 2006. * In December 2015, the Buccaneers and the Tampa Sports Authority reached an agreement to complete over $100 million in improvements and renovations to the stadium. The negotiations took months, and were extended by Bucs' lawyers demanding additional concessions after an agreement was near in September 2015.{{cite news | url=http://events.tbo.com/news/localgovernment/how-the-raymond-james-stadium-negotiations-between-the-buccaneers-and-the/2248015 | title=How the Raymond James Stadium negotiations between the Buccaneers and the Tampa Sports Authority broke down | work=Tampa Tribune / tbo.com | date=1 October 2015 | accessdate=29 August 2016 | author=Contorno, Steve | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160915001936/http://events.tbo.com/news/localgovernment/how-the-raymond-james-stadium-negotiations-between-the-buccaneers-and-the/2248015 | archive-date=September 15, 2016 | dead-url=yes | df=mdy-all }} In the end, the upgrades were paid with at least $29 million of public money, with the remainder paid for by the Bucs in exchange for the right to play a home game at another site beginning in the 2018 season and other concessions. Renovations began in January 2016, and the first phase was complete in time for the 2016 football season.{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/local/2015/12/02/bucs-strike-raymond-james-stadium-renovation-deal/76653190/ | title=Bucs strike deal with county on stadium renovations | work=USA Today / WTSP | date=3 December 2015 | accessdate=28 August 2016 | author=Pransky, Noah}} {{wide image|RJSPAN.jpg|1000px|alt=Panoramic view from The Pirate Ship during the 2009 off-season|Panoramic view from The Pirate Ship during the 2009 off-season}} ==Notable football games== ===Super Bowl=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#efefef;" ! style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Tampa Bay Buccaneers|border=2}};|Season ! style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Tampa Bay Buccaneers|border=2}};|Game ! style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Tampa Bay Buccaneers|border=2}};|Date ! style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Tampa Bay Buccaneers|border=2}};|Winning team ! style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|Tampa Bay Buccaneers|border=2}};|Score ! football|Alabama]] 31: January 9, 2017 ([[2017 College Football Playoff National Championship]], largest crowd in stadium history – 74,512) ==Soccer== The stadium was also home to the former [[Tampa Bay Mutiny]] of [[Major League Soccer]] and continues to periodically host other soccer matches due to its accommodating field dimensions. For example, on June 8, 2012, it hosted the [[United States men's national soccer team]]'s opening qualifying match against Antigua and Barbuda for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]], which the United States won 3-1.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/09/sports/soccer/a-world-cup-qualifying-victory-lacks-quality-for-the-us.html | work=The New York Times | first=John | last=Godfrey | title=A World Cup Qualifying Victory Lacks Quality for the U.S | date=June 9, 2012}} In October 11, 2018, the [[Colombia men's national soccer team]] played against the [[United States men's national soccer team]] (4-2) to set the current attendance record of 38,361 for a soccer match at this stadium.{{cn|date=October 2018}} ===International Soccer Matches=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:95%;" style="text-align:center" |- !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Tampa Bay Buccaneers|border=2}};"|Date !style="text-align:center; {{NFLPrimaryStyle|Tampa Bay Buccaneers|border=2}};"|Winning Team !style="text-align:center; (5 titles) | broadcasters = [[TrueVisions]] }} The '''League Cup''' ({{lang-th|ไทยลีกคัพ}}) is a [[association football|football]] cup competition in [[Thailand]]. It is also known as '''Toyota League Cup''' for sponsorship reasons.{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/th/news/4318/%E0%B9%82%E0%B8%95%E0%B9%82%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%95%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%B2-%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B5%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%9E/2016/08/16/26581782/7-%E0%B9%82%E0%B8%A1%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%97%E0%B9%8C%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%95%E0%B9%8C%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%AA%E0%B8%99%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%AB%E0%B9%8C%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%95%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%94%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%8A%E0%B8%B7%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%81%E0%B9%82%E0%B8%95%E0%B9%82%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%95%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B5%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%9E|title=7 โมเมนท์มนต์เสน่ห์รอบตัดเชือกโตโยต้าลีกคัพ|language=Thai|accessdate=2016-08-16}} It was re-formed during the 2010 domestic football league season in Thailand and runs along the same lines as the [[Thai FA Cup]] except that the earlier rounds would be regional rather than an open draw.{{cite web|url=http://www.toyotaleaguecup.com/history.php|title=โตโยต้า ลีก คัพ |language=Thai|accessdate=2010-08-14}} == Final == [[File:Toyota League Cup Trophy.jpg|thumb|right|Toyota League Cup Trophy]] {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !scope=col|Year !scope=col|Winner !scope=col class="unsortable"|Score !scope=col|Runners-up !scope=col|Venue |-style="background: #DFE6EF;" |- !scope=row style=text-align:center| 1987 |[[Royal Thai Air Force FC|Royal Thai Air Force]] | | | |- !scope=row style=text-align:center| 1988 |[[Bangkok Bank FC|Bangkok Bank]] | | | |- !scope=row style=text-align:center| 1989 |[[Royal Thai Police FC|Royal Thai Police]] | | | |- !scope=row style=text-align:center| 1990 |Bangkok

the [[Football Association of Thailand]] and [[Thai League 1]] and is divided into eight rounds,; the remaining Thai League teams enter at the first round,Matches in all rounds are single-legged, except for the semi-finals, which have been two-legged since the competition began.In single-legged top division teams will plays as away team.The semi-finals were the exception to this,which the away goals rule and penalties were introduced. For finals match that have finished level after extra time have been decided by penalty shoot-out.The winner also qualify for [[Mekong Club Championship]]. ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.toyotaleaguecup.com/hall_of_fame_3.php Official Website] {{Thai League Cup seasons}} {{Football in Thailand}} {{National football (soccer) league cups}} [[Category:Thai League Cup| ]] [[Category:Football cup competitions in Thailand|2]] [[Category:National association football cups]] [[Category:Recurring sporting events established in 2010]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Thailand]] {{Thailand-footy-competition-stub}}

page.title: Training the Three-Day Event Horse and Rider

revision.comment: Replace [[Help:Magic links|magic links]] with templates per [[Special:Permalink/772743896#Future of magic links|local RfC]] and [[:mw:Requests for comment/Future of magic links|MediaWiki RfC]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Training the Three-Day Event Horse and Rider''''' ({{ISBN|0-385-42520-1}}) is a 1995 book written by [[James C. Wofford]], covering each phase of the [[Equestrianism|equestrian]] sport of [[eventing]], as well as a brief history of the event and a section on choosing a proper horse for the sport. The book ends with a section on conditioning and interval training, and provides several grids for gymnastic jumping. The book is considered a classic by American eventers.
The book is part of the [[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]] Equestrian Library Series (Doubleday, NY). It began printing in 1995, was discontinued, and then began reprinting in 2006.
==Chapters== * History and Development of the Three-Day Event * Selecting and Evaluating the Three-Day Prospect * Equipment for Horse and Rider * Dressage * Cross-Country * Show Jumping * Conditioning * Putting It All Together ** Appendix I: Interval Notation and Conditioning Gallops ** Appendix II: Sample Schedules ** Appendix III: Gymnastic Show Jumping
[[Category:1995 books]] [[Category:Books about sports]] [[Category:Eventing]] [[Category:Doubleday (publisher) books]]
{{sport-book-stub}}

The '''Western Michigan University Soccer Complex''' is a [[soccer-specific stadium]] located in [[Kalamazoo, Michigan]] on the campus of [[Western Michigan University]]. Originally known as Lee Baker Field, the complex is adjacent to WMU's Business, Technology & Research Park and the Engineering College campus, and is home to both the [[Western Michigan Broncos]] [[Western Michigan Broncos men's soccer|men's]] and [[Western Michigan Broncos women's soccer|women's]] soccer teams. The stands seat about 500, and there is standing room along the fencelines, particularly on the north and west sides.
The stadium opened in 2005. The first upgrades were in 2012, when the field was fenced and team shelters were added. A paved parking lot, a formal entry and walkways, and a press box were added in 2013. New bleacher seating was installed in 2015, <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wmubroncos.com/sports/2016/7/25/wmu-soccer-complex.aspx?id=1340 |title=WMU Soccer Complex |publisher=Western Michigan University |accessdate=August 30, 2017 }}</ref>
The grass turf of the playing field received a major overhaul of during the summer of 2017 with removal of the top layer of soil by fraze mowing, laser-guided grading, and a new drainage system.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/college/2017/04/22/western-michigan-broncos-soccer-complex-renovation/100778608/ |title=Metro & state: WMU getting $75,000 renovations at soccer complex |publisher=Detroit Free Press |date=April 22, 2017 |accessdate=August 30, 2017 }}</ref> At the same time, a new scoreboard was installed along with new fencing, a new flagpole, and new nets behind the goals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wmubroncos.com/facilities/?id=11 |title=WMU Soccer Complex |publisher=Western Michigan University |accessdate=August 30, 2017 }}</ref>
In addition to the stadium, the complex includes a full-sized practice field, electronic scoreboard and sound system, covered bench shelters, and a concession stand with a storage shed.
== References == {{reflist}} == External links == [http://www.wmubroncos.com/facilities/?id=11 WMU Soccer Complex]
{{Western Michigan University}}
